<type>file</type>
<content>1: ## src: https://github.com/victoryforphil/elysia-protobuf/blob/master/README.md
2: 
3: # elysia-protobuf
4: 
5: Easy support protobuf integration for Elysia. To decode/encode we use [@bufbuild/protobuf](https://github.com/bufbuild/protobuf-es) lib and schemas generated by [ts-proto](https://github.com/stephenh/ts-proto)
6: 
7: ## Install
8: 
9: ```bash
10: bun install elysia-protobuf
11: ```
12: 
13: ## Before starting
14: 
15: Lib is incompatible with default elysia body/response validation! Don't mix it with `parse: "protobuf"`!
16: 
17: ## Usage
18: 
19: **✅ Do**: Use requestSchema field and import decode from context
20: 
21: ```ts
22: import Elysia from "elysia";
23: import {
24:   protobuf,
25:   ProtoRequestError,
26:   ProtoResponseError,
27: } from "elysia-protobuf";
28: import {
29:   RequestMessage,
30:   ResponseMessage,
31:   ResponseStatus,
32: } from "./proto/message";
33: 
34: const app = new Elysia()
35:   .use(
36:     protobuf({
37:       schemas: {
38:         "post.request": RequestMessage,
39:         "post.response": ResponseMessage,
40:       },
41:       // (optional) verify body with signature
42:       signature: {
43:         enabled: true,
44:         secret: "test123",
45:         headerName: "x-signature",
46:       },
47:     }),
48:   )
49:   .post(
50:     "/post",
51:     async ({ body, decode, headers }) => {
52:       // decode uint8array with your schema
53:       const data = await decode("post.request", body, headers);
54:       console.log(data);
55:       return {
56:         status: ResponseStatus.SOME,
57:         inlineTags: data.tags.join(", "),
58:       };
59:     },
60:     {
61:       // parse body as arrayBuffer -> Uint8Array
62:       parse: "protobuf",
63:       // encode response with protobuf schema
64:       responseSchema: "post.response",
65:     },
66:   )
67:   .listen(3000);
68: ```
69: 
70: **❌ Don't**: Use default body/response elysia validation with `parse: "protobuf"`
71: 
72: ```ts
73: // ...
74: const app = new Elysia()
75:   .use(
76:     protobuf({
77:       schemas: {
78:         "post.request": RequestMessage,
79:         "post.response": ResponseMessage,
80:       },
81:     }),
82:   )
83:   .post(
84:     "/post",
85:     async ({ body, decode }) => {
86:       // decode uint8array with your schema
87:       const data = await decode("post.request", body);
88:       console.log(data);
89:       return {
90:         status: ResponseStatus.SOME,
91:         inlineTags: data.tags.join(", "),
92:       };
93:     },
94:     {
95:       parse: "protobuf",
96:       responseSchema: "post.response",
97:       // ! ❌ INCOMPATIBLE with `parse: "protobuf"`
98:       //   body: t.Object({
99:       //     title: t.String(),
100:       //     updatedAt: t.Optional(t.Number()),
101:       //     tags: t.Array(t.String()),
102:       //   }),
103:       // Doubtful But Okay
104:       // body: t.Uint8Array(),
105:     },
106:   )
107:   .post(
108:     "/json",
109:     ({ body }) => {
110:       return body;
111:     },
112:     {
113:       // OK if parse mode isn't protobuf
114:       body: t.Object({
115:         title: t.String(),
116:         updatedAt: t.Optional(t.Number()),
117:         tags: t.Array(t.String()),
118:       }),
119:     },
120:   )
121:   .listen(3000);
122: ```
123: 
124: You can handle plugin errors with onError event
125: 
126: ```ts
127: import { protobuf, ProtoRequestError, ProtoResponseError } from "../../src";
128: // ...
129: 
130: const app = new Elysia()
131:   .use(
132:     protobuf({
133:       schemas: {
134:         "post.request": RequestMessage,
135:         "post.response": ResponseMessage,
136:       },
137:     }),
138:   )
139:   .error({
140:     PROTO_RESPONSE_ERROR: ProtoResponseError,
141:     PROTO_REQUEST_ERROR: ProtoRequestError,
142:   })
143:   .onError(({ code, error, set }) => {
144:     // something like that
145:     switch (code) {
146:       case "PROTO_REQUEST_ERROR": {
147:         set.status = 400;
148:         break;
149:       }
150:       case "PROTO_RESPONSE_ERROR": {
151:         set.status = 500;
152:         break;
153:       }
154:     }
155: 
156:     return {
157:       message: (error as Error).message,
158:     };
159:   });
160: // ...
161: ```
162: 
163: You can only parse protobuf body as `Uint8Array` with use only `protobufParser`
164: 
165: ```ts
166: import { protobufParser } from "../src";
167: 
168: const app = new Elysia().use(protobufParser()).post("/a", ({ body }) => body, {
169:   parse: "protobuf",
170: });
171: ```
172: 
173: ### Create protobuf schema:
174: 
175: 1. Install [protoc](https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/releases)
176: 2. Install [ts-proto](https://github.com/stephenh/ts-proto) package
177: 3. Convert `.proto` to `.ts` with ts-proto (see [example](./example/) for details):
178: 
179: ```bash
180: protoc --plugin=.\\node_modules\\.bin\\protoc-gen-ts_proto --ts_proto_opt=esModuleInterop=true --ts_proto_opt=importSuffix=.js --ts_proto_out=./src ./proto/*.proto
181: ```
182: 
183: 4. Import schemas from `./src/proto/YOUR_FILE.ts`
184: 
185: ## Options
186: 
187: | Key       | Type      | Default   | Description        |
188: | --------- | --------- | --------- | ------------------ |
189: | schemas   | Schemas   | {}        | key - proto schema |
190: | signature | Signature | undefined | signature settings |
191: 
192: ```ts
193: new Elysia().use(
194:   protobuf({
195:     schemas: {
196:       // any string key: proto schema
197:       "post.request": RequestMessage,
198:       "post.response": ResponseMessage,
199:     },
200:     signature: {
201:       // disabled by default
202:       enabled: true,
203:       secret: "changeme",
204:       headerName: "x-signature",
205:     },
206:   }),
207: );
208: ```
209: 

(End of file - total 209 lines)
</content>

<path>/Users/alex/repos/vfp/dark-factory/README.md</path>
<type>file</type>
<content>1: # Dark Factory - Autonomous Agentic Development At Scale
2: 
3: # Concept
4: 
5: - A central `dark-factory` "core" is used to track `products`
6: - A `product` is the canonical definition of a code product we want to work on
7:   - In Stage 0 this is identified by a local path-based locator key
8:   - Locators are path/url-like identifiers, currently using `@local://{abs_path}`
9:   - `product` may optionally include a `display_name` for human-friendly rendering
10: - A `variant` is a spawned instance of a `product` where work actually runs
11:   - In Stage 0 a product immediately gets one default variant on creation
12:   - Variant identity follows the same locator pattern with a fragment suffix:
13:     - `@local://{abs_path}#default`
14:   - Future variants can use other suffixes (example: `#wt-main`) when we support parallel instances
15: - Stage 0 topology is intentionally strict and simple:
16:   - One product locator
17:   - One default variant locator
18:   - One actor bound to that variant
19: - `actor` is a spawned agent that operates on a variant
20:   - Can be various agent backends (currently scoped in OpenCode, Codex and a custom agent), but first iteration is JUST OpenCode
21:   - Future work will allow multiple variants per product and multiple actors where operations allow
22: 
23: # Stack + Tools
24: 
25: - Agentic Coding: `opencode`
26: - Main languages: `rust` and `bun` / `typescript`
27: - Scripting: shebanged Bun TypeScript scripts under `scripts/` (`*.sh.ts`)
28: - Optional build system: `moon` / `proto`
29: - Common Schema Definition: `prisma`
30:   - [ ] TODO: Investigate use of protobuf
31: 
32: # Scripts
33: 
34: - Project shell-style scripts are Bun TypeScript files with shebangs: `#!/usr/bin/env bun`.
35: - Shared helpers live in `scripts/helpers/`.
36: - `scripts/install.sh.ts` runs an ordered array of install steps from repository root.
37: - `scripts/proto_install.sh.ts` runs `proto install` from repository root.
38: - `scripts/scrape_moon_docs.sh.ts` captures moonrepo docs as split per-page `docs/external/moonrepo/*.ext.md` files plus `docs/external/moonrepo/index.ext.md`.
39: - `scripts/scrape_opencode_docs.sh.ts` captures OpenCode docs as split per-page `docs/external/opencode/*.ext.md` files plus `docs/external/opencode/index.ext.md`.
40:   - Defaults to English docs only (`DOCS_LANGUAGE=en`), with optional override via `DOCS_LANGUAGE`.
41: - OpenCode skill reference: `.opencode/skills/proto-install/SKILL.md`.
42: - OpenCode skill reference: `.opencode/skills/script-authoring/SKILL.md`.
43: - OpenCode skill reference: `.opencode/skills/docs-scraping/SKILL.md`.
44: 
45: # Components
46: 
47: ## Core
48: 
49: - Central service that manages tracking of all products/variants/actors/settings, etc.
50:   - TBD: will either be stateless w/ DB and route all commands just to the agents
51:     - OR: a background API service (REST even) we can query from frontends
52: - Currently looks like it will be Bun + Elysia JS
53: 
54: ## Frontends
55: 
56: - Various frontends that invoke / connect to Core
57: - Main way of iterating with the system
58: - Uses the Core API to communicate (REST / WS or GRPC in the future)
59: - Some Frontends:
60:   - Rust TUI (Ratatui.rs) - First One
61:   - Web Client (Bun + Vite + Shadcn + React)
62:   - Pure CLI (Rust)
63: 
64: ## Agents
65: 
66: - Abstracted communication with actual agents doing work
67: - First is OpenCode
68: 

(End of file - total 68 lines)
</content>

metadata.preview:
# Dark Factory Core

This package is the early `core` service for the `dark-factory` project.

It currently provides a small Bun + Elysia HTTP service that acts as a starting point for Core APIs around:

- `product` tracking
- `variant` management
- `actor` orchestration

## Current Status

- Early bootstrap service
- No database or persistence wired yet
- No validated test/lint/typecheck commands yet

## Endpoints (Current)

- `GET /` returns service metadata and project concepts

<content>1: #!/usr/bin/env bun
2: import { dirname, join, resolve } from "node:path";
3: import { existsSync } from "node:fs";
4: 
5: export function findRepoRoot(startDir: string = import.meta.dir): string {
6:   let current = resolve(startDir);
7: 
8:   while (true) {
9:     if (existsSync(join(current, ".git"))) {
10:       return current;
11:     }
12: 
13:     const parent = dirname(current);
14:     if (parent === current) {
15:       throw new Error(`Could not find repository root from: ${startDir}`);
16:     }
17: 
18:     current = parent;
19:   }
20: }
21:

2: ## External Docs Snapshot // moonrepo

10: 
11: Source: https://moonrepo.dev/docs/setup-workspace
12: 
13: # Setup workspace
14: 
15: 2 min
16: 
17: Once moon has been [installed](/docs/install), we must setup the [workspace](/docs/concepts/workspace),
18: which is denoted by the `.moon` folder — this is known as the workspace root. The workspace is in
19: charge of:
20: 
21: - Integrating with a version control system.
22: 
23: - Defining configuration that applies to its entire tree.
24: 
25: - Housing [projects](/docs/concepts/project) to build a [project graph](/docs/how-it-works/project-graph).
26: 
27: - Running tasks with the [action graph](/docs/how-it-works/action-graph).
28: 
29: ## Initializing the repository
30: 
31: Let's scaffold and initialize moon in a repository with the [`moon init`](/docs/commands/init) command.
32: This should typically be ran at the root, but can be nested within a directory.
33: 
34: ```
35: $ moon init
36: ```
37: 
38: When executed, the following operations will be applied.
39: 
40: - Creates a `.moon` folder with a [`.moon/workspace.yml`](/docs/config/workspace) configuration file.
41: 
42: - Appends necessary ignore patterns to the relative `.gitignore`.
43: 
44: - Infers the version control system from the environment.
45: 
46: info
47: 
48: If you're investigating moon, or merely want to prototype, you can use `moon init --minimal` to
49: quickly initialize and create minimal configuration files.
50: 
51: ## Migrate from an existing build system
52: 
53: Looking to migrate from Nx or Turborepo to moon? Use our
54: [`moon ext migrate-nx`](/docs/guides/extensions#migrate-nx) or
55: [`moon ext migrate-turborepo`](/docs/guides/extensions#migrate-turborepo) commands for a (somewhat)
56: seamless migration!
57: 
58: These extensions will convert your existing configuration files to moon's format as best as
59: possible, but is not a requirement.
60: 
61: ## Configuring a version control system
62: 
63: moon requires a version control system (VCS) to be present for functionality like file diffing,
64: hashing, and revision comparison. The VCS and its default branch can be configured through the
65: [`vcs`](/docs/config/workspace#vcs) setting.
66: 
67: .moon/workspace.yml
68: 
69: ```
70: vcs:  manager: 'git'  defaultBranch: 'master'
71: ```
72: 
73: moon defaults to `git` and the settings above, so feel free to skip this.
74: 
75: ## Next steps
76: 
77: [Create a project](/docs/create-project)[Configure `.moon/workspace.yml` further](/docs/config/workspace)[Learn about the workspace](/docs/concepts/workspace)
78: 
79: ----
80: ## Notes / Comments / Lessons
81: 
82: - Collection method: sitemap discovery + markdown conversion.
83: - Conversion path: direct HTML fallback parser.
84: - This file is one page-level external snapshot in markdown `.ext.md` format.
85: ----
86: 

(End of file - total 86 lines)
</content>

<type>file</type>
<content>1: ----
2: ## External Docs Snapshot // moonrepo
3: 
4: - Captured: 2026-02-16T03:48:02.472Z
5: - Source root: https://moonrepo.dev/docs
6: - Source page: /docs/config/workspace
7: - Keywords: moon, moonrepo, docs, monorepo, build, config, workspace
8: - Summary: The `.moon/workspace.yml` file configures projects and services in the workspace. This file is
9: ----
10: 
11: Source: https://moonrepo.dev/docs/config/workspace
12: 
13: # .moon/workspace
14: 
15: The `.moon/workspace.yml` file configures projects and services in the workspace. This file is
16: required.
17: 
18: ## `extends`
19: 
20: Defines one or many external `.moon/workspace.yml`'s to extend and inherit settings from. Perfect
21: for reusability and sharing configuration across repositories and projects. When defined, this
22: setting must be an HTTPS URL or relative file system path that points to a valid YAML document!
23: 
24: .moon/workspace.yml
25: 
26: ```
27: extends: 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/organization/repository/master/.moon/workspace.yml'
28: ```
29: 
30: info
31: 
32: Settings will be merged recursively for blocks, with values defined in the local configuration
33: taking precedence over those defined in the extended configuration. However, the `projects` setting
34: does not merge!
35: 
36: ## `projects`Required
37: 
38: Defines the location of all [projects](/docs/concepts/project) within the workspace. Supports either a
39: manual map of projects (default), a list of globs in which to automatically locate projects, or
40: both.
41: 
42: caution
43: 
44: Projects that depend on each other and form a cycle must be avoided! While we do our best to avoid
45: an infinite loop and disconnect nodes from each other, there's no guarantee that tasks will run in
46: the correct order.
47: 
48: ### Using a map
49: 
50: When using a map, each project must be manually configured and requires a unique
51: [name](/docs/concepts/project#names) as the map key, where this name is used heavily on the command
52: line and within the project graph for uniquely identifying the project amongst all projects. The map
53: value (known as the project source) is a file system path to the project folder, relative from the
54: workspace root, and must be contained within the workspace boundary.
55: 
56: .moon/workspace.yml
57: 
58: ```
59: projects:  admin: 'apps/admin'  apiClients: 'packages/api-clients'  designSystem: 'packages/design-system'  web: 'apps/web'
60: ```
61: 
62: ### Using globs
63: 
64: If manually mapping projects is too tedious or cumbersome, you may provide a list of
65: [globs](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#globs) to automatically locate all project folders, relative from
66: the workspace root.
67: 
68: When using this approach, the project name is derived from the project folder name, and is cleaned
69: to our [supported characters](/docs/concepts/project#names), but can be customized with the
70: [`id`](/docs/config/project#id) setting in [`moon.yml`](/docs/config/project). Furthermore, globbing does risk the
71: chance of collision, and when that happens, we log a warning and skip the conflicting project from
72: being configured in the project graph.
73: 
74: .moon/workspace.yml
75: 
76: ```
77: projects:  - 'apps/*'  - 'packages/*'  # Only shared folders with a moon configuration  - 'shared/*/moon.yml'
78: ```
79: 
80: ### Using a map and globs
81: 
82: For those situations where you want to use both patterns, you can! The list of globs can be
83: defined under a `globs` field, while the map of projects under a `sources` field.
84: 
85: .moon/workspace.yml
86: 
87: ```
88: projects:  globs:    - 'apps/*'    - 'packages/*'  sources:    www: 'www'
89: ```
90: 
91: Additionally, you can customize the format of project IDs for glob discovered projects. By default
92: it inherits the fodler name, but this has a high chance of collision. Instead you can configure
93: `globFormat` to use a different format, for example, using the full workspace relative path as the
94: project ID.
95: 
96: .moon/workspace.yml
97: 
98: ```
99: projects:  globFormat: 'source-path'  globs:    - 'packages/**/moon.yml'
100: ```
101: 
102: ## `defaultProject`v2.0.0
103: 
104: Defines the default project to focus on when no project scope is specified on the command line for
105: task targets.
106: 
107: .moon/workspace.yml
108: 
109: ```
110: defaultProject: 'web'
111: ```
112: 
113: ## `codeowners`v1.8.0
114: 
115: Configures code owners (`CODEOWNERS`) integration across the entire workspace.
116: 
117: ### `globalPaths`
118: 
119: This setting defines file patterns and their owners at the workspace-level, and are applied to any
120: matching path, at any depth, within the entire workspace. This is useful for defining global or
121: fallback owners when a granular [project-level path](/docs/config/project#paths) does not match or exist.
122: 
123: .moon/workspace.yml
124: 
125: ```
126: codeowners:  globalPaths:    '*': ['@admins']    'config/': ['@infra']    '/.github/': ['@infra']
127: ```
128: 
129: ### `orderBy`
130: 
131: The order in which code owners, grouped by project, are listed in the `CODEOWNERS` file. Accepts
132: "file-source" (default) or "project-id".
133: 
134: .moon/workspace.yml
135: 
136: ```
137: codeowners:  orderBy: 'project-id'
138: ```
139: 
140: ### `sync`
141: 
142: Will automatically generate a `CODEOWNERS` file by aggregating and syncing all project
143: [`owners`](/docs/config/project#owners) in the workspace when a [target is run](/docs/concepts/target). The format
144: and location of the `CODEOWNERS` file is based on the [`vcs.provider`](#provider) setting. Defaults
145: to `false`.
146: 
147: .moon/workspace.yml
148: 
149: ```
150: codeowners:  sync: true
151: ```
152: 
153: ## `constraints`
154: 
155: Configures constraints between projects that are enforced during project graph generation. This is
156: also known as project boundaries.
157: 
158: ### `enforceLayerRelationships`
159: 
160: Enforces allowed relationships between a project and its dependencies based on the project's
161: [`layer`](/docs/config/project#layer) and [`stack`](/docs/config/project#stack) settings. When a project depends on
162: another project of an invalid layer, a layering violation error will be thrown when attempting to
163: run a task.
164: 
165: Layers are allowed to depend on lower layers in the same stack, but not higher layers. Additionally,
166: layers may depend on itself, excluding automations and applications. The following layers are
167: stacked as such:
168: 
169: Layer Description
170: 
171: `automation` An automated testing suite, like E2E, integration, or visual tests.
172: 
173: `application` An application of any kind.
174: 
175: `tool` An internal tool, CLI, one-off script, etc.
176: 
177: `library` A self-contained, shareable, and publishable set of code.
178: 
179: `scaffolding` Templates or generators for scaffolding.
180: 
181: `configuration` Configuration files or infrastructure.
182: 
183: `unknown` When not configured.
184: 
185: When the project `stack` setting is defined, it alters these rules to allow these kinds of
186: relationships. For example, a frontend application can depend on a backend application, but not
187: another frontend application.
188: 
189: .moon/workspace.yml
190: 
191: ```
192: constraints:  enforceLayerRelationships: false
193: ```
194: 
195: Projects with an unconfigured or unknown layer are ignored during enforcement.
196: 
197: ### `tagRelationships`
198: 
199: Enforces allowed relationships between a project and its dependencies based on the project's
200: [`tags`](/docs/config/project#tags) setting. This works in a similar fashion to `enforceLayerRelationships`,
201: but gives you far more control over what these relationships look like.
202: 
203: For example, let's enforce that Next.js projects using the `next` tag can only depend on React
204: projects using the `react` tag. If a dependency does not have one of the configured required tags,
205: in this case `react`, an error will occur.
206: 
207: .moon/workspace.yml
208: 
209: ```
210: constraints:  tagRelationships:    next: ['react']
211: ```
212: 
213: On the project side, we would configure [`moon.yml`](/docs/config/project#tags) like so:
214: 
215: app/moon.yml
216: 
217: ```
218: tags: ['next']dependsOn: ['components']
219: ```
220: 
221: packages/components/moon.yml
222: 
223: ```
224: tags: ['react']
225: ```
226: 
227: ## `docker`v1.27.0
228: 
229: Configures Docker integration for the entire workspace.
230: 
231: ### `prune`
232: 
233: Configures aspects of the Docker pruning process when
234: [`moon docker prune`](/docs/commands/docker/prune) is executed.
235: 
236: #### `deleteVendorDirectories`
237: 
238: Automatically delete vendor directories (package manager dependencies, build targets, etc) while
239: pruning. For example, `node_modules` for JavaScript, or `target` for Rust. Defaults to `true`.
240: 
241: .moon/workspace.yml
242: 
243: ```
244: docker:  prune:    deleteVendorDirectories: false
245: ```
246: 
247: This process happens before toolchain dependencies are installed.
248: 
249: #### `installToolchainDependencies`
250: 
251: Automatically install production dependencies for all required toolchain's of the focused projects
252: within the Docker build. For example, `node_modules` for JavaScript. Defaults to `true`.
253: 
254: .moon/workspace.yml
255: 
256: ```
257: docker:  prune:    installToolchainDependencies: false
258: ```
259: 
260: This process happens after vendor directories are deleted.
261: 
262: ### `scaffold`
263: 
264: Configures aspects of the Docker scaffolding process when
265: [`moon docker scaffold`](/docs/commands/docker/scaffold) is executed. Only applies to the
266: [workspace skeleton](/docs/commands/docker/scaffold#workspace).
267: 
268: #### `configsPhaseGlobs`
269: 
270: List of globs in which to copy additional workspace-relative files into the `.moon/docker/workspace`
271: skeleton. When not defined, does nothing.
272: 
273: .moon/workspace.yml
274: 
275: ```
276: docker:  scaffold:    configsPhaseGlobs:      - '**/package.json'
277: ```
278: 
279: ## `experiments`v1.11.0
280: 
281: Enable or disable experiments that alter core functionality.
282: 
283: warning
284: 
285: Experiments are a work in progress and may be buggy. Please report any issues you encounter!
286: 
287: ### `fasterGlobWalk`v1.34.0
288: 
289: Utilizes a new concurrent glob walking implementation that is on average, 1.5-2x faster than the
290: current implementation. Additionally, common globs are now cached for the duration of the process.
291: Defaults to `true`.
292: 
293: .moon/workspace.yml
294: 
295: ```
296: experiments:  fasterGlobWalk: true
297: ```
298: 
299: ### `gitV2`v1.34.0
300: 
301: Utilizes a Git implementation, that has better support for submodules, subtrees, and workspaces.
302: Additionally, processes are parallized when applicable. Defaults to `true`.
303: 
304: .moon/workspace.yml
305: 
306: ```
307: experiments:  gitV2: true
308: ```
309: 
310: ## `generator`
311: 
312: Configures aspects of the template generator.
313: 
314: ### `templates`
315: 
316: A list of paths in which templates can be located. Supports the following types of paths, and
317: defaults to `./templates`.
318: 
319: - File system paths, relative from the workspace root.
320: 
321: - Git repositories and a revision, prefixed with `git://`. v1.23.0
322: 
323: - npm packages and a version, prefixed with `npm://`. v1.23.0
324: 
325: .moon/workspace.yml
326: 
327: ```
328: generator:  templates:    - './templates'    - 'file://./other/templates'    - 'git://github.com/moonrepo/templates#master'    - 'npm://@moonrepo/templates#1.2.3'
329: ```
330: 
331: Learn more about this in the official
332: [code generation guide](/docs/guides/codegen#configuring-template-locations)!
333: 
334: ## `hasher`
335: 
336: Configures aspects of the smart hashing layer.
337: 
338: ### `ignoreMissingPatterns`v1.10.0
339: 
340: When [`hasher.warnOnMissingInputs`](#warnonmissinginputs) is enabled, moon will log a warning to the
341: terminal that an input is missing. This is useful for uncovering misconfigurations, but can be quite
342: noisy when inputs are truly optional.
343: 
344: To ignore warnings for missing inputs, a list of [glob patterns](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#globs) can
345: be configured to filter and ignore files. Files are matched against workspace relative paths, so
346: prefixing patterns with `**/` is suggested.
347: 
348: .moon/workspace.yml
349: 
350: ```
351: hasher:  ignoreMissingPatterns:    - '**/.eslintrc.*'    - '**/*.config.*'
352: ```
353: 
354: ### `ignorePatterns`v1.10.0
355: 
356: A list of [glob patterns](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#globs) used to filter and ignore files during the
357: inputs hashing process. Files are matched against workspace relative paths, so prefixing patterns
358: with `**/` is suggested.
359: 
360: .moon/workspace.yml
361: 
362: ```
363: hasher:  ignorePatterns:    - '**/*.png'
364: ```
365: 
366: ### `optimization`
367: 
368: Determines the optimization level to utilize when hashing content before running targets.
369: 
370: - `accuracy` (default) - When hashing dependency versions, utilize the resolved value in the lockfile. This requires parsing the lockfile, which may reduce performance.
371: 
372: - `performance` - When hashing dependency versions, utilize the value defined in the manifest. This is typically a version range or requirement.
373: 
374: .moon/workspace.yml
375: 
376: ```
377: hasher:  optimization: 'performance'
378: ```
379: 
380: ### `walkStrategy`
381: 
382: Defines the file system walking strategy to utilize when discovering inputs to hash.
383: 
384: - `glob` - Walks the file system using glob patterns.
385: 
386: - `vcs` (default) - Calls out to the [VCS](#vcs) to extract files from its working tree.
387: 
388: .moon/workspace.yml
389: 
390: ```
391: hasher:  walkStrategy: 'glob'
392: ```
393: 
394: ### `warnOnMissingInputs`
395: 
396: When enabled, will log warnings to the console when attempting to hash an input that does not exist.
397: This is useful in uncovering misconfigured tasks. Defaults to `true`.
398: 
399: .moon/workspace.yml
400: 
401: ```
402: hasher:  warnOnMissingInputs: false
403: ```
404: 
405: ## `notifier`
406: 
407: Configures how moon notifies and interacts with a developer or an external system.
408: 
409: ### `terminalNotifications`v1.38.0
410: 
411: When defined, will display OS notifications for action pipeline events when running commands from a
412: terminal. Supports the following values:
413: 
414: - `always` - Display on pipeline success and failure.
415: 
416: - `failure` - Display on pipeline failure only.
417: 
418: - `success` - Display on pipeline success only.
419: 
420: - `task-failure` - Display for each task failure.
421: 
422: .moon/workspace.yml
423: 
424: ```
425: notifier:  terminalNotifications: 'always'
426: ```
427: 
428: ### `webhookUrl`
429: 
430: Defines an HTTPS URL that all pipeline events will be posted to. View the
431: [webhooks guide for more information](/docs/guides/webhooks) on available events.
432: 
433: .moon/workspace.yml
434: 
435: ```
436: notifier:  webhookUrl: 'https://api.company.com/some/endpoint'
437: ```
438: 
439: ### `acknowledge`
440: 
441: When enabled, webhook notifier will wait for request result and validates the return code for 2xx.
442: Defaults to `false`.
443: 
444: warning
445: 
446: Activating this setting will slow down your pipeline, because every webhook request will be
447: evaluated!
448: 
449: .moon/workspace.yml
450: 
451: ```
452: notifier:  webhookUrl: 'https://api.company.com/some/endpoint'  webhookAcknowledge: true
453: ```
454: 
455: ## `pipeline`
456: 
457: Configures aspects of task running and the action pipeline.
458: 
459: ### `autoCleanCache`v1.24.0
460: 
461: Automatically cleans cached artifacts older than [`cacheLifetime`](#cachelifetime) from the cache
462: directory (`.moon/cache`) after every run. This is useful for keeping the cache directory lean.
463: Defaults to `true`.
464: 
465: .moon/workspace.yml
466: 
467: ```
468: pipeline:  autoCleanCache: false
469: ```
470: 
471: ### `cacheLifetime`
472: 
473: The maximum lifetime of cached artifacts before they're marked as stale and automatically removed by
474: the action pipeline. Defaults to "7 days". This field requires an integer and a timeframe unit that
475: can be [parsed as a duration](https://docs.rs/humantime/2.1.0/humantime/fn.parse_duration.html).
476: 
477: .moon/workspace.yml
478: 
479: ```
480: pipeline:  cacheLifetime: '24 hours'
481: ```
482: 
483: ### `inheritColorsForPipedTasks`
484: 
485: Force colors to be inherited from the current terminal for all tasks that are ran as a child process
486: and their output is piped to the action pipeline. Defaults to `true`.
487: [View more about color handling in moon](/docs/commands/overview#colors).
488: 
489: .moon/workspace.yml
490: 
491: ```
492: pipeline:  inheritColorsForPipedTasks: true
493: ```
494: 
495: ### `installDependencies`v1.34.0
496: 
497: When enabled, runs the
498: [`InstallWorkspaceDeps` and `InstallProjectDeps` actions](/docs/how-it-works/action-graph#install-dependencies)
499: within the pipeline before running an applicable task. Installation is determined based on changed
500: manifests and lockfiles. Defaults to `true`.
501: 
502: .moon/workspace.yml
503: 
504: ```
505: pipeline:  installDependencies: false
506: ```
507: 
508: Instead of a boolean, a list of toolchain IDs can be provided to only allow those toolchains to
509: install dependencies.
510: 
511: .moon/workspace.yml
512: 
513: ```
514: pipeline:  installDependencies: ['node']
515: ```
516: 
517: ### `killProcessThreshold`v1.32.1
518: 
519: Threshold in milliseconds in which to force kill running child processes after the pipeline receives
520: an external signal (like `SIGINT` or `SIGTERM`). A value of 0 will not kill the process and let them
521: run to completion. Defaults to `2000` (2 seconds).
522: 
523: .moon/workspace.yml
524: 
525: ```
526: pipeline:  killProcessThreshold: 5000
527: ```
528: 
529: ### `logRunningCommand`
530: 
531: When enabled, will log the task's command, resolved arguments, and working directory when a target
532: is ran. Defaults to `false`.
533: 
534: .moon/workspace.yml
535: 
536: ```
537: pipeline:  logRunningCommand: true
538: ```
539: 
540: ### `syncProjects`v1.34.0
541: 
542: When enabled, runs the [`SyncProject` action](/docs/how-it-works/action-graph#sync-project) within the
543: pipeline before running an applicable task. Defaults to `true`.
544: 
545: .moon/workspace.yml
546: 
547: ```
548: pipeline:  syncProjects: false
549: ```
550: 
551: Instead of a boolean, a list of project IDs can be provided to only sync those projects.
552: 
553: .moon/workspace.yml
554: 
555: ```
556: pipeline:  syncProjects: ['app']
557: ```
558: 
559: The [`moon sync projects`](/docs/commands/sync/projects) command can be executed to manually sync
560: projects.
561: 
562: ### `syncWorkspace`v1.34.0
563: 
564: When enabled, runs the [`SyncWorkspace` action](/docs/how-it-works/action-graph#sync-workspace) within
565: the pipeline before all other actions. This syncing includes operations such as codeowners, VCS
566: hooks, and more. Defaults to `true`.
567: 
568: .moon/workspace.yml
569: 
570: ```
571: pipeline:  syncWorkspace: false
572: ```
573: 
574: The [`moon sync ...`](/docs/commands/sync) sub-commands can be executed to manually sync features.
575: 
576: ## `remote`v1.30.0
577: 
578: Configures a remote service, primarily for cloud-based caching of artifacts. Learn more about this
579: in the [remote caching](/docs/guides/remote-cache) guide.
580: 
581: ### `api`v1.32.0
582: 
583: The API format of the remote server. This format dictates which type of client moon uses for
584: communicating with. Supports the following:
585: 
586: - `grpc` (default) - Uses the gRPC API: [https://github.com/bazelbuild/remote-apis](https://github.com/bazelbuild/remote-apis)
587: 
588: - `http` - Uses the HTTP API: [https://bazel.build/remote/caching#http-caching](https://bazel.build/remote/caching#http-caching)
589: 
590: .moon/workspace.yml
591: 
592: ```
593: remote:  api: 'grpc'
594: ```
595: 
596: ### `auth`v1.32.0
597: 
598: Configures authorization and authentication level features of our remote clients.
599: 
600: #### `headers`v1.32.0
601: 
602: A mapping of HTTP headers to include in all requests to the remote server. These headers are applied
603: to all [API formats and protocols](#api), not just HTTP.
604: 
605: .moon/workspace.yml
606: 
607: ```
608: remote:  auth:    headers:      'X-Custom-Header': 'value'
609: ```
610: 
611: #### `token`v1.32.0
612: 
613: The name of an environment variable in which to extract a token for
614: [Bearer HTTP authorization](https://swagger.io/docs/specification/v3_0/authentication/bearer-authentication/).
615: An `Authorization` HTTP header will be included in all requests to the remote server.
616: 
617: If the token does not exist, or is not enabled, remote caching will be disabled.
618: 
619: .moon/workspace.yml
620: 
621: ```
622: remote:  auth:    token: 'ENV_VAR_NAME'
623: ```
624: 
625: ### `cache`
626: 
627: Configures aspects of the caching layer, primarily the action cache (AC) and content addressable
628: cache (CAS).
629: 
630: #### `compression`v1.31.0
631: 
632: The compression format to use when uploading/downloading blobs. Supports `none` and `zstd`, and
633: defaults to no compression (`identity` format in RE API).
634: 
635: .moon/workspace.yml
636: 
637: ```
638: remote:  cache:    compression: 'zstd'
639: ```
640: 
641: info
642: 
643: Compression is only applied to gRPC based APIs, not HTTP.
644: 
645: #### `instanceName`
646: 
647: A
648: [unique identifier](https://github.com/bazelbuild/remote-apis/blob/main/build/bazel/remote/execution/v2/remote_execution.proto#L223)
649: used to distinguish between the various instances on the host. This allows the same remote service
650: to serve and partition multiple moon repositories. Defaults to `moon-outputs`.
651: 
652: .moon/workspace.yml
653: 
654: ```
655: remote:  cache:    instanceName: 'custom-dir-name'
656: ```
657: 
658: We suggest changing the instance name to the name of your repository!
659: 
660: #### `localReadOnly`v1.40.0
661: 
662: When enabled and developing locally, existing remote blobs will only be downloaded, but new local
663: blobs will not be uploaded. Blobs will only be uploaded in CI environments.
664: 
665: .moon/workspace.yml
666: 
667: ```
668: remote:  cache:    localReadOnly: true
669: ```
670: 
671: #### `verifyIntegrity`v1.36.0
672: 
673: When downloading blobs, verify the digests/hashes in the response match the associated blob
674: contents. This will reduce performance but ensure partial or corrupted blobs won't cause failures.
675: Defaults to `false`.
676: 
677: .moon/workspace.yml
678: 
679: ```
680: remote:  cache:    verifyIntegrity: true
681: ```
682: 
683: ### `host`
684: 
685: The host URL to communicate with when uploading and downloading artifacts. Supports both
686: `grpc(s)://` and `http(s)://` protocols. This field is required!
687: 
688: .moon/workspace.yml
689: 
690: ```
691: remote:  host: 'grpcs://your-host.com:9092'
692: ```
693: 
694: ### `mtls`
695: 
696: Connect to the host using server and client authentication with mTLS. This takes precedence over
697: normal TLS.
698: 
699: .moon/workspace.yml
700: 
701: ```
702: remote:  # ...  mtls:    caCert: 'certs/ca.pem'    clientCert: 'certs/client.pem'    clientKey: 'certs/client.key'    domain: 'your-host.com'
703: ```
704: 
705: #### `assumeHttp2`
706: 
707: If true, assume that the host supports HTTP/2, even if it doesn't provide protocol negotiation via
708: ALPN.
709: 
710: #### `caCert`
711: 
712: A file path, relative from the workspace root, to the certificate authority PEM encoded X509
713: certificate (typically `ca.pem`).
714: 
715: #### `clientCert`
716: 
717: A file path, relative from the workspace root, to the client's PEM encoded X509 certificate
718: (typically `client.pem`).
719: 
720: #### `clientKey`
721: 
722: A file path, relative from the workspace root, to the client's PEM encoded X509 private key
723: (typically `client.key`).
724: 
725: #### `domain`
726: 
727: The domain name in which to verify the TLS certificate.
728: 
729: ### `tls`
730: 
731: Connect to the host using server-only authentication with TLS.
732: 
733: .moon/workspace.yml
734: 
735: ```
736: remote:  # ...  tls:    cert: 'certs/ca.pem'    domain: 'your-host.com'
737: ```
738: 
739: #### `assumeHttp2`
740: 
741: If true, assume that the host supports HTTP/2, even if it doesn't provide protocol negotiation via
742: ALPN.
743: 
744: #### `cert`
745: 
746: A file path, relative from the workspace root, to the certificate authority PEM encoded X509
747: certificate (typically `ca.pem`).
748: 
749: #### `domain`
750: 
751: The domain name in which to verify the TLS certificate.
752: 
753: ## `telemetry`
754: 
755: When enabled, will check for a newer moon version and send anonymous usage data to the moonrepo
756: team. This data is used to improve the quality and reliability of the tool. Defaults to `true`.
757: 
758: .moon/workspace.yml
759: 
760: ```
761: telemetry: false
762: ```
763: 
764: ## `vcs`
765: 
766: Configures the version control system to utilize within the workspace (and repository). A VCS is
767: required for determining touched (added, modified, etc) files, calculating file hashes, computing
768: affected files, and much more.
769: 
770: ### `defaultBranch`
771: 
772: Defines the default branch in the repository for comparing differences against. For git, this is
773: typically "master" (default) or "main".
774: 
775: .moon/workspace.yml
776: 
777: ```
778: vcs:  defaultBranch: 'master'
779: ```
780: 
781: ### `hooks`v1.9.0
782: 
783: Defines a mapping of hooks to a list of commands to run when that event is triggered. There are no
784: restrictions to what commands can be run, but the binaries for each command must exist on each
785: machine that will be running hooks.
786: 
787: For Git, each [hook name](https://git-scm.com/docs/githooks#_hooks) must be a valid kebab-cased
788: name. [Learn more about Git hooks](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Customizing-Git-Git-Hooks).
789: 
790: .moon/workspace.yml
791: 
792: ```
793: vcs:  hooks:    pre-commit:      - 'moon run :lint :format --affected --status=staged --no-bail'      - 'another-command'
794: ```
795: 
796: info
797: 
798: If running `moon` commands directly, the `moon` binary must be installed globally!
799: 
800: ### `hookFormat`v1.29.0
801: 
802: The shell and file type in which generated hook files are formatted with. Supports the following:
803: 
804: - `native` (default) - The format native to the current operating system. Bash on Unix, and PowerShell on Windows.
805: 
806: - `bash` - Forces the format to Bash for all operating systems.
807: 
808: .moon/workspace.yml
809: 
810: ```
811: vcs:  hookFormat: 'bash'
812: ```
813: 
814: ### `client`
815: 
816: Defines the VCS tool/binary that is being used for managing the repository. Accepts "git" (default).
817: Expect more version control systems in the future!
818: 
819: .moon/workspace.yml
820: 
821: ```
822: vcs:  client: 'git'
823: ```
824: 
825: ### `provider`v1.8.0
826: 
827: Defines the service provider that the repository is hosted on. Accepts "github" (default), "gitlab",
828: "bitbucket", or "other".
829: 
830: .moon/workspace.yml
831: 
832: ```
833: vcs:  provider: 'github'
834: ```
835: 
836: ### `remoteCandidates`
837: 
838: (Git only) Defines a list of remote candidates to query against to determine merge bases. Defaults
839: to "origin" and "upstream".
840: 
841: .moon/workspace.yml
842: 
843: ```
844: vcs:  remoteCandidates:    - 'origin'    - 'upstream'
845: ```
846: 
847: ### `sync`v1.9.0
848: 
849: Will automatically generate [hook scripts](#hooks) to `.moon/hooks` and sync the scripts to the
850: local VCS checkout. The hooks format and location is based on the [`vcs.client`](#client) setting.
851: Defaults to `false`.
852: 
853: .moon/workspace.yml
854: 
855: ```
856: vcs:  hooks:    # ...  sync: true
857: ```
858: 
859: caution
860: 
861: When enabled, this will sync hooks for all users of the repository. For personal or small
862: projects, this may be fine, but for larger projects, this may be undesirable and disruptive!
863: 
864: ## `versionConstraint`
865: 
866: Defines a version requirement for the currently running moon binary. This provides a mechanism for
867: enforcing that the globally installed moon on every developers machine is using an applicable
868: version.
869: 
870: .moon/workspace.yml
871: 
872: ```
873: versionConstraint: '>=0.20.0'
874: ```
875: 
876: ----
877: ## Notes / Comments / Lessons
878: 
879: - Collection method: sitemap discovery + markdown conversion.
880: - Conversion path: direct HTML fallback parser.
881: - This file is one page-level external snapshot in markdown `.ext.md` format.
882: ----
883: 

(End of file - total 883 lines)

Source: https://moonrepo.dev/docs/config/workspace

# .moon/workspace

The `.moon/workspace.yml` file configures projects and services in the workspace. This file is
required.

## `extends`

Defines one or many external `.moon/workspace.yml`'s to extend and inherit settings from. Perfect
