<type>file</type>
<content>1: ----
2: ## External Docs Snapshot // moonrepo
3: 
4: - Captured: 2026-02-16T03:48:02.472Z
5: - Source root: https://moonrepo.dev/docs
6: - Source page: /docs/config/project
7: - Keywords: moon, moonrepo, docs, monorepo, build, config, project
8: - Summary: The `moon.yml` configuration file is not required but can be used to define additional metadata
9: ----
10: 
11: Source: https://moonrepo.dev/docs/config/project
12: 
13: # moon
14: 
15: The `moon.yml` configuration file is not required but can be used to define additional metadata
16: for a project, override inherited tasks, and more at the project-level. When used, this file must
17: exist in a project's root, as configured in [`projects`](/docs/config/workspace#projects).
18: 
19: ## `dependsOn`
20: 
21: Explicitly defines other projects that this project depends on, primarily when generating the
22: project and task graphs. The most common use case for this is building those projects before
23: building this one. When defined, this setting requires an array of project names, which are the keys
24: found in the [`projects`](/docs/config/workspace#projects) map.
25: 
26: moon.yml
27: 
28: ```
29: dependsOn:  - 'apiClients'  - 'designSystem'
30: ```
31: 
32: A dependency object can also be defined, where a specific `scope` can be assigned, which accepts
33: "production" (default), "development", "build", or "peer".
34: 
35: moon.yml
36: 
37: ```
38: dependsOn:  - id: 'apiClients'    scope: 'production'  - id: 'designSystem'    scope: 'peer'
39: ```
40: 
41: Learn more about [implicit and explicit dependencies](/docs/concepts/project#dependencies).
42: 
43: ## Metadata
44: 
45: ## `id`v1.18.0
46: 
47: Overrides the name (identifier) of the project, which was configured in or derived from the
48: [`projects`](/docs/config/workspace#projects) setting in [`.moon/workspace.yml`](/docs/config/workspace). This setting is
49: useful when using glob based project location, and want to avoid using the folder name as the
50: project name.
51: 
52: moon.yml
53: 
54: ```
55: id: 'custom-id'
56: ```
57: 
58: info
59: 
60: All references to the project must use the new identifier, including project and task dependencies.
61: 
62: ## `language`
63: 
64: The primary programming language the project is written in. This setting is required for
65: [task inheritance](/docs/config/tasks), editor extensions, and more. Supports the following values:
66: 
67: - `bash` - A [Bash](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bash_(Unix_shell)) based project (Unix only).
68: 
69: - `batch` - A [Batch](https://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/Windows_Batch_Scripting)/PowerShell based project (Windows only).
70: 
71: - `go` - A [Go](https://go.dev/) based project.
72: 
73: - `javascript` - A [JavaScript](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript) based project.
74: 
75: - `php` - A [PHP](https://www.php.net) based project.
76: 
77: - `python` - A [Python](https://www.python.org/) based project.
78: 
79: - `ruby` - A [Ruby](https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/) based project.
80: 
81: - `rust` - A [Rust](https://www.rust-lang.org/) based project.
82: 
83: - `typescript` - A [TypeScript](https://www.typescriptlang.org/) based project.
84: 
85: - `unknown` (default) - When not configured or inferred.
86: 
87: - `*` - A custom language. Values will be converted to kebab-case.
88: 
89: moon.yml
90: 
91: ```
92: language: 'javascript'# Customlanguage: 'kotlin'
93: ```
94: 
95: For convenience, when this setting is not defined, moon will attempt to detect the language based
96: on configuration files found in the project root. This only applies to non-custom languages!
97: 
98: ## `owners`v1.8.0
99: 
100: Defines ownership of source code within the current project, by mapping file system paths to owners.
101: An owner is either a user, team, or group.
102: 
103: Currently supports
104: [GitHub](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/managing-your-repositorys-settings-and-features/customizing-your-repository/about-code-owners),
105: [GitLab](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/codeowners/reference.html), and
106: [Bitbucket](https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1218598/code-owners-for-bitbucket?tab=overview&hosting=cloud)
107: (via app).
108: 
109: ### `customGroups`Bitbucket
110: 
111: When using the
112: [Code Owners for Bitbucket](https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1218598/code-owners-for-bitbucket?tab=overview&hosting=cloud)
113: app, this setting provides a way to define custom groups that will be injected at the top of the
114: `CODEOWNERS` file. These groups must be unique across all projects.
115: 
116: moon.yml
117: 
118: ```
119: owners:  customGroups:    '@@@backend': ['@"user name"', '@@team']
120: ```
121: 
122: ### `defaultOwner`
123: 
124: The default owner for all [`paths`](#paths). This setting is optional in some cases but helps to
125: avoid unnecessary repetition.
126: 
127: moon.yml
128: 
129: ```
130: owners:  defaultOwner: '@frontend'
131: ```
132: 
133: ### `optional`GitLab
134: 
135: For GitLab, marks the project's
136: [code owners section](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/codeowners/reference.html#optional-sections)
137: as optional. Defaults to `false`.
138: 
139: moon.yml
140: 
141: ```
142: owners:  optional: true
143: ```
144: 
145: ### `paths`
146: 
147: The primary setting for defining ownership of source code within the current project. This setting
148: supports 2 formats, the first being a list of file paths relative from the current project. This
149: format requires [`defaultOwner`](#defaultowner) to be defined, and only supports 1 owner for every
150: path (the default owner).
151: 
152: moon.yml
153: 
154: ```
155: owners:  defaultOwner: '@frontend'  paths:    - '**/*.ts'    - '**/*.tsx'    - '*.config.js'
156: ```
157: 
158: The second format provides far more granularity, allowing for multiple owners per path. This format
159: requires a map, where the key is a file path relative from the current project, and the value is a
160: list of owners. Paths with an empty list of owners will fallback to [`defaultOwner`](#defaultowner).
161: 
162: moon.yml
163: 
164: ```
165: owners:  defaultOwner: '@frontend'  paths:    '**/*.rs': ['@backend']    '**/*.js': []    '*.config.js': ['@frontend', '@frontend-infra']
166: ```
167: 
168: The syntax for owners is dependent on the provider you are using for version control (GitHub,
169: GitLab, Bitbucket). moon provides no validation or guarantees that these are correct.
170: 
171: ### `requiredApprovals`Bitbucket / GitLab
172: 
173: Requires a specific number of approvals for a pull/merge request to be satisfied. Defaults to `1`.
174: 
175: - For Bitbucket, defines the [`Check()` condition](https://docs.mibexsoftware.com/codeowners/merge-checks#MergeChecks-2.MergeChecks:HowmanyoftheseCodeOwnersneedtoapprovebeforeapullrequestcanbemerged?) when using a [`defaultOwner`](#defaultowner).
176: 
177: - For GitLab, defines a requirement on the [code owners section](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/codeowners/reference.html#sections-requiring-multiple-approvals).
178: 
179: moon.yml
180: 
181: ```
182: owners:  requiredApprovals: 2
183: ```
184: 
185: ## `layer`
186: 
187: The layer within a [stack](#stack). Supports the following values:
188: 
189: - `application` - An application of any kind.
190: 
191: - `automation` - An automated testing suite, like E2E, integration, or visual tests. v1.16.0
192: 
193: - `configuration` - Configuration files or infrastructure. v1.22.0
194: 
195: - `library` - A self-contained, shareable, and publishable set of code.
196: 
197: - `scaffolding` - Templates or generators for scaffolding. v1.22.0
198: 
199: - `tool` - An internal tool, CLI, one-off script, etc.
200: 
201: - `unknown` (default) - When not configured.
202: 
203: moon.yml
204: 
205: ```
206: layer: 'application'
207: ```
208: 
209: info
210: 
211: The project layer is used in [task inheritance](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance),
212: [constraints and boundaries](/docs/config/workspace#constraints), editor extensions, and more!
213: 
214: ## `project`
215: 
216: The `project` setting defines metadata about the project itself.
217: 
218: moon.yml
219: 
220: ```
221: project:  title: 'moon'  description: 'A monorepo management tool.'  channel: '#moon'  owner: 'infra.platform'  maintainers: ['miles.johnson']
222: ```
223: 
224: The information listed within `project` is purely informational and primarily displayed within the
225: CLI. However, this setting exists for you, your team, and your company, as a means to identify and
226: organize all projects. Feel free to build your own tooling around these settings!
227: 
228: ### `channel`
229: 
230: The Slack, Discord, Teams, IRC, etc channel name (with leading #) in which to discuss the project.
231: 
232: ### `description`Required
233: 
234: A description of what the project does and aims to achieve. Be as descriptive as possible, as this
235: is the kind of information search engines would index on.
236: 
237: ### `maintainers`
238: 
239: A list of people/developers that maintain the project, review code changes, and can provide support.
240: Can be a name, email, LDAP name, GitHub username, etc, the choice is yours.
241: 
242: ### `title`
243: 
244: A human readable name of the project. This is different from the unique project name configured in
245: [`projects`](/docs/config/workspace#projects).
246: 
247: ### `owner`
248: 
249: The team or organization that owns the project. Can be a title, LDAP name, GitHub team, etc. We
250: suggest not listing people/developers as the owner, use [maintainers](#maintainers) instead.
251: 
252: ### Custom fieldsv2.0.0
253: 
254: Additional fields can be configured as custom metadata to associate to this project. Supports all
255: value types that are valid JSON.
256: 
257: moon.yml
258: 
259: ```
260: project:  # ...  deprecated: true
261: ```
262: 
263: ## `stack`v1.22.0
264: 
265: The technology stack this project belongs to, primarily for categorization. Supports the following
266: values:
267: 
268: - `backend` - Server-side APIs, etc.
269: 
270: - `data` - Data sources, database layers, etc. v2.0.0
271: 
272: - `frontend` - Client-side user interfaces, etc.
273: 
274: - `infrastructure` - Cloud/server infrastructure, Docker, etc.
275: 
276: - `systems` - Low-level systems programming.
277: 
278: - `unknown` (default) - When not configured.
279: 
280: moon.yml
281: 
282: ```
283: stack: 'frontend'
284: ```
285: 
286: info
287: 
288: The project stack is also used in [constraints and boundaries](/docs/config/workspace#constraints)!
289: 
290: ## `tags`
291: 
292: Tags are a simple mechanism for categorizing projects. They can be used to group projects together
293: for [easier querying](/docs/commands/query/projects), enforcing of
294: [project boundaries and constraints](/docs/config/workspace#constraints),
295: [task inheritance](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance), and more.
296: 
297: moon.yml
298: 
299: ```
300: tags:  - 'react'  - 'prisma'
301: ```
302: 
303: ## Integrations
304: 
305: ## `docker`v1.27.0
306: 
307: Configures Docker integration for the current project.
308: 
309: ### `file`
310: 
311: Configures the `Dockerfile` generation process when [`moon docker file`](/docs/commands/docker/file) is
312: executed.
313: 
314: #### `buildTask`
315: 
316: The name of a task within the current project that will be used for building the project before
317: running it. If not defined, does nothing.
318: 
319: moon.yml
320: 
321: ```
322: docker:  file:    buildTask: 'build'
323: ```
324: 
325: #### `image`
326: 
327: The Docker image to use in the base stage. Defaults to an image based on the project's toolchain, as
328: outlined below.
329: 
330: - `oven/bun:latest` for Bun
331: 
332: - `denoland/deno:latest` for Deno
333: 
334: - `node:latest` for Node.js
335: 
336: - `python:latest` for Python
337: 
338: - `rust:latest` for Rust
339: 
340: - `scratch` for everything else
341: 
342: moon.yml
343: 
344: ```
345: docker:  file:    image: 'node:latest'
346: ```
347: 
348: #### `startTask`
349: 
350: The name of a task within the current project that will run the project after it has been built (if
351: required). This task will be used as `CMD` within the `Dockerfile`.
352: 
353: moon.yml
354: 
355: ```
356: docker:  file:    startTask: 'start'
357: ```
358: 
359: ### `scaffold`
360: 
361: Configures aspects of the Docker scaffolding process when
362: [`moon docker scaffold`](/docs/commands/docker/scaffold) is executed. Only applies to the
363: [sources skeleton](/docs/commands/docker/scaffold#sources).
364: 
365: #### `sourcesPhaseGlobs`
366: 
367: List of globs in which to copy project-relative files into the `.moon/docker/sources` skeleton. When
368: not defined, defaults to `**/*`.
369: 
370: moon.yml
371: 
372: ```
373: docker:  scaffold:    sourcesPhaseGlobs:      - 'src/**/*'
374: ```
375: 
376: ## Tasks
377: 
378: ## `env`
379: 
380: The `env` field is map of strings that are passed as environment variables to all tasks within the
381: current project. Project-level variables will not override task-level variables of the same name.
382: 
383: moon.yml
384: 
385: ```
386: env:  NODE_ENV: 'production'
387: ```
388: 
389: View the task [`env`](#env-1) setting for more usage examples and information.
390: 
391: ## `fileGroups`
392: 
393: Defines [file groups](/docs/concepts/file-group) to be used by local tasks. By default, this setting
394: is not required for the following reasons:
395: 
396: - File groups are an optional feature, and are designed for advanced use cases.
397: 
398: - File groups defined in [`.moon/tasks/all.yml`](/docs/config/tasks) will be inherited by all projects.
399: 
400: When defined this setting requires a map, where the key is the file group name, and the value is a
401: list of [globs or file paths](/docs/concepts/file-pattern), or environment variables. Globs and paths
402: are [relative to a project](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#project-relative) (even when defined
403: [globally](/docs/config/tasks)).
404: 
405: moon.yml
406: 
407: ```
408: # Example groupsfileGroups:  configs:    - '*.config.{js,cjs,mjs}'    - '*.json'  sources:    - 'src/**/*'    - 'types/**/*'  tests:    - 'tests/**/*'    - '**/__tests__/**/*'  assets:    - 'assets/**/*'    - 'images/**/*'    - 'static/**/*'    - '**/*.{scss,css}'
409: ```
410: 
411: Once your groups have been defined, you can reference them within [`args`](#args),
412: [`inputs`](#inputs), [`outputs`](#outputs), and more, using
413: [token functions and variables](/docs/concepts/token).
414: 
415: moon.yml
416: 
417: ```
418: tasks:  build:    command: 'vite build'    inputs:      - '@group(configs)'      - '@group(sources)'
419: ```
420: 
421: ## `tasks`
422: 
423: Tasks are actions that are ran within the context of a [project](/docs/concepts/project), and commonly
424: wrap an npm binary or system command. This setting requires a map, where the key is a unique name
425: for the task, and the value is an object of task parameters.
426: 
427: moon.yml
428: 
429: ```
430: tasks:  format:    command: 'prettier'  lint:    command: 'eslint'  test:    command: 'jest'  typecheck:    command: 'tsc'
431: ```
432: 
433: ### `extends`v1.12.0
434: 
435: The `extends` field can be used to extend the settings from a sibling task within the same project,
436: or [inherited from the global scope](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance). This is useful for composing
437: similar tasks with different arguments or options.
438: 
439: When extending another task, the same
440: [merge strategies](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance#merge-strategies) used for inheritance are applied.
441: 
442: moon.yml
443: 
444: ```
445: tasks:  lint:    command: 'eslint .'    inputs:      - 'src/**/*'  lint-fix:    extends: 'lint'    args: '--fix'    preset: 'utility'
446: ```
447: 
448: ### `description`v1.22.0
449: 
450: A human-readable description of what the task does. This information is displayed within the
451: [`moon project`](/docs/commands/project) and [`moon task`](/docs/commands/task) commands.
452: 
453: moon.yml
454: 
455: ```
456: tasks:  build:    description: 'Builds the project using Vite'    command: 'vite build'
457: ```
458: 
459: ### `command`
460: 
461: The `command` field is a single command to execute for the task, including the command binary/name
462: (must be first) and any optional [arguments](#args). This field supports task inheritance and
463: merging of arguments.
464: 
465: This setting can be defined using a string, or an array of strings. We suggest using arrays when
466: dealing with many args, or the args string cannot be parsed easily.
467: 
468: moon.yml
469: 
470: ```
471: tasks:  format:    # Using a string    command: 'prettier --check .'    # Using an array    command:      - 'prettier'      - '--check'      - '.'
472: ```
473: 
474: info
475: 
476: If you need to support pipes, redirects, or multiple commands, use [`script`](#script) instead.
477: Learn more about [commands vs scripts](/docs/concepts/task#commands-vs-scripts).
478: 
479: #### Special commands
480: 
481: For interoperability reasons, the following command names have special handling.
482: 
483: - `noop`, `no-op`, `nop` - Marks the task as a "no operation". Will not execute a command in the action pipeline but can define dependencies.
484: 
485: - When `toolchain` is "bun": `bun`, `bunx` - Uses the binaries from the toolchain.
486: 
487: - When `toolchain` is "deno": Will execute with `deno` binary.
488: 
489: - When `toolchain` is "node": `node`, `npm`, `pnpm`, `yarn` - Uses the binaries from the toolchain.
490: 
491: - When `toolchain` is "rust": Will execute with `cargo` binary.
492: 
493: ### `args`
494: 
495: The `args` field is a collection of additional arguments to append to the [`command`](#command)
496: when executing the task. This field exists purely to provide arguments for
497: [inherited tasks](/docs/config/tasks#tasks).
498: 
499: This setting can be defined using a string, or an array of strings. We suggest using arrays when
500: dealing with many args, or the args string cannot be parsed easily.
501: 
502: moon.yml
503: 
504: ```
505: tasks:  test:    command: 'jest'    # Using a string    args: '--color --maxWorkers 3'    # Using an array    args:      - '--color'      - '--maxWorkers'      - '3'
506: ```
507: 
508: However, for the array approach to work correctly, each argument must be its own distinct item,
509: including argument values. For example:
510: 
511: moon.yml
512: 
513: ```
514: tasks:  test:    command: 'jest'    args:      # Valid      - '--maxWorkers'      - '3'      # Also valid      - '--maxWorkers=3'      # Invalid      - '--maxWorkers 3'
515: ```
516: 
517: ### `deps`
518: 
519: The `deps` field is a list of other tasks (known as [targets](/docs/concepts/target)), either within
520: this project or found in another project, that will be executed before this task. It achieves this
521: by generating a directed task graph based on the project graph.
522: 
523: moon.yml
524: 
525: ```
526: tasks:  build:    command: 'webpack'    deps:      - 'apiClients:build'      - 'designSystem:build'      # A task within the current project      - 'codegen'
527: ```
528: 
529: #### Args & env
530: 
531: Furthermore, for each dependency target, you can configure additional command line arguments and
532: environment variables that'll be passed to the dependent task when it is ran. The `args` field
533: supports a list of strings, while `env` is an object of key-value pairs.
534: 
535: moon.yml
536: 
537: ```
538: tasks:  build:    command: 'webpack'    deps:      - target: 'apiClients:build'        args: ['--env', 'production']        env:          NODE_ENV: 'production'
539: ```
540: 
541: Dependencies of inherited tasks will be excluded and renamed according to the
542: [`workspace.inheritedTasks`](#inheritedtasks) setting. This process only uses filters from the
543: current project, and not filters from dependent projects. Furthermore, `args` and `env` are not
544: deeply merged.
545: 
546: #### Optional
547: 
548: By default, all dependencies are required to exist when tasks are being built and expanded, but this
549: isn't always true when dealing with composition and inheritance. For dependencies that may not exist
550: based on what's inherited, you can mark it as `optional`.
551: 
552: moon.yml
553: 
554: ```
555: tasks:  build:    command: 'webpack'    deps:      - target: 'apiClients:build'        optional: true
556: ```
557: 
558: ### `env`
559: 
560: The `env` field is map of strings that are passed as environment variables when running the command.
561: Variables defined here will take precedence over those loaded with [`envFile`](#envfile).
562: 
563: moon.yml
564: 
565: ```
566: tasks:  build:    command: 'webpack'    env:      NODE_ENV: 'production'
567: ```
568: 
569: Variables also support substitution using the syntax `${VAR_NAME}`. When using substitution, only
570: variables in the current process can be referenced, and not those currently defined in `env`.
571: 
572: moon.yml
573: 
574: ```
575: tasks:  build:    command: 'webpack'    env:      APP_TARGET: '${REGION}-${ENVIRONMENT}'
576: ```
577: 
578: ### `inputs`
579: 
580: The `inputs` field is a list of sources that calculate whether to execute this task based on the
581: environment and files that have been touched since the last time the task has been ran. If not
582: defined or inherited, then all files within a project are considered an input (`**/*`), excluding
583: root-level tasks.
584: 
585: Inputs support the following source types:
586: 
587: - Environment variables
588: 
589: - Environment variable wildcards v1.22.0
590: 
591: - Files, folders, and globs
592: 
593: - [Token functions and variables](/docs/concepts/token)
594: 
595: moon.yml
596: 
597: ```
598: tasks:  lint:    command: 'eslint'    inputs:      # Config files anywhere within the project      - '**/.eslintignore'      - '**/.eslintrc.js'      # Config files at the workspace root      - '/.eslintignore'      - '/.eslintrc.js'      # Tokens      - '$projectRoot'      - '@group(sources)'
599: ```
600: 
601: #### Environment variables
602: 
603: Environment variables can be used as inputs and must start with a `$`. Wildcard variables can use
604: `*` to match any character.
605: 
606: moon.yml
607: 
608: ```
609: tasks:  example:    inputs:      - '$FOO_CACHE'      - '$FOO_*'
610: ```
611: 
612: caution
613: 
614: When using an environment variable, we assume it's not defined by default, and will trigger an
615: affected state when it is defined. If the environment variable always exists, then the task will
616: always run and bypass the cache.
617: 
618: #### File paths
619: 
620: File paths support
621: [project and workspace relative file/folder patterns](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#project-relative).
622: They can be defined as a literal path, or a `file://` URI v1.39.0,
623: or as an object with a `file` property v1.39.0. Additionally, the
624: following parameters are supported as a URI query or as object fields:
625: 
626: - `content`, `match`, `matches` (`string`) - When determining affected state, will match against the file's content using the defined regex pattern, instead of relying on file existence.
627: 
628: - `optional` (`boolean`) - When hashing and set to `true` and the file is missing, will not log a warning. When set to `false` and the file is missing, will fail with an error. Defaults to logging a warning.
629: 
630: moon.yml
631: 
632: ```
633: tasks:  example:    inputs:      # Literal paths      - 'project/relative/file.js'      - '/workspace/relative/file.js'      # Using file protocol      - 'file://project/relative/file.js?optional'      - 'file:///workspace/relative/file.js?content=a|b|c'      # Using an object      - file: 'project/relative/file.js'        optional: true      - file: '/workspace/relative/file.js'        content: 'a|b|c'
634: ```
635: 
636: #### File groupsv1.41.0
637: 
638: A file group input will reference the defined files/globs within from a file group in the current
639: project. It can be defined with a `group://` URI, or as an object with a `group` property.
640: Additionally, the following parameters are supported as a URI query or as object fields:
641: 
642: - `format`, `as` (`string`) - The format in which to gather the file group results. Supported values are `static` (default), `files`, `dirs`, `globs`, `envs`, and `root`.
643: 
644: moon.yml
645: 
646: ```
647: fileGroups:  sources:    - 'src/**/*'tasks:  build:    # ...    inputs:      # Using group protocol      - 'group://sources?format=dirs'      # Using an object      - group: 'sources'        format: 'dirs'
648: ```
649: 
650: #### Glob patterns
651: 
652: Glob patterns support
653: [project and workspace relative file/folder patterns](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#project-relative).
654: They can be defined as a literal path, or a `glob://` URI v1.39.0,
655: or as an object with a `glob` property v1.39.0. Additionally, the
656: following parameters are supported as a URI query or as object fields:
657: 
658: - `cache` (`boolean`) - When gathering inputs for hashing, defines whether the glob results should be cached for the duration of the moon process. Defaults to `true`.
659: 
660: moon.yml
661: 
662: ```
663: tasks:  example:    inputs:      # Literal paths      - 'project/relative/file.*'      - '/workspace/relative/**/*'      # Using glob protocol      - 'glob://project/relative/file.*?cache=false'      - 'glob:///workspace/relative/**/*?cache'      # Using an object      - glob: 'project/relative/file.*'        cache: false      - glob: '/workspace/relative/**/*'
664: ```
665: 
666: Globs can also be negated by prefixing the path with `!`, which will exclude all files that match
667: the glob.
668: 
669: moon.yml
670: 
671: ```
672: tasks:  example:    inputs:      - '!**/*.md'      - 'glob://!/workspace/relative/**/*'      - glob: '!/workspace/relative/**/*'
673: ```
674: 
675: warning
676: 
677: Glob patterns that contain `?`, for example `*.tsx?`, cannot be used in URI format, as it conflicts
678: with the query string syntax. Use the path or object format instead.
679: 
680: danger
681: 
682: Be aware that files that match the glob, but are ignored via `.gitignore` (or similar), will not
683: be considered an input. To work around this, use explicit file inputs.
684: 
685: #### External projectsv1.41.0
686: 
687: Tasks can also depend on files and globs from other projects within the same workspace. This is
688: useful for handling cross-project relationships without needing to define explicit task
689: dependencies.
690: 
691: External projects can be defined as a `project://` URI, or as an object with a `project` property,
692: both of which require a project identifier, or `^` for all dependent projects. Additionally, the
693: following parameters are supported as a URI query or as object fields:
694: 
695: - `group`, `fileGroup` (`id`) - The name of a file group within the external project in which file and glob patterns will be used for matching. Takes precedence over `filter`.
696: 
697: - `filter` (`string[]`) - A list of [project relative glob patterns](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#project-relative) that will be used for matching.
698: 
699: If neither `group` nor `filter` are defined, all files within the external project are considered a
700: match (`**/*`).
701: 
702: moon.yml
703: 
704: ```
705: tasks:  example:    inputs:      # Using project protocol      - 'project://foo'      - 'project://bar?group=sources'      - 'project://baz?filter=src/**/*'      # Using an object      - project: 'foo'      - project: 'bar'        group: 'sources'      - project: 'baz'        filter: ['src/**/*']
706: ```
707: 
708: ### `outputs`
709: 
710: The `outputs` field is a list of [files and folders](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#project-relative) that
711: are created as a result of executing this task, typically from a build or compilation related
712: task. Outputs are necessary for [incremental caching and hydration](/docs/concepts/cache). If you'd
713: prefer to avoid that functionality, omit this field.
714: 
715: #### File paths
716: 
717: File paths support
718: [project and workspace relative file/folder patterns](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#project-relative).
719: They can be defined as a literal path, or a `file://` URI v1.41.0,
720: or as an object with a `file` property v1.41.0. Additionally, the
721: following parameters are supported as a URI query or as object fields:
722: 
723: - `optional` (`boolean`) - When archiving and set to `true` and the file is missing, will not fail with a missing output error. Defaults to `false`.
724: 
725: moon.yml
726: 
727: ```
728: tasks:  example:    inputs:      # Literal paths      - 'build/'      # Using file protocol      - 'file://build/'      # Using an object      - file: 'build/'        optional: true
729: ```
730: 
731: #### Glob patterns
732: 
733: Glob patterns support
734: [project and workspace relative file/folder patterns](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#project-relative).
735: They can be defined as a literal path, or a `glob://` URI v1.41.0,
736: or as an object with a `glob` property v1.41.0. Additionally, the
737: following parameters are supported as a URI query or as object fields:
738: 
739: - `optional` (`boolean`) - When archiving and set to `true` and the glob produced no results, will not fail with a missing output error. Defaults to `false`.
740: 
741: moon.yml
742: 
743: ```
744: tasks:  example:    inputs:      # Literal paths      - 'build/**/*.js'      - '!build/internal.js'      # Using glob protocol      - 'glob://build/**/*.js'      # Using an object      - glob: 'build/**/*.js'
745: ```
746: 
747: warning
748: 
749: Glob patterns that contain `?`, for example `*.tsx?`, cannot be used in URI format, as it conflicts
750: with the query string syntax. Use the path or object format instead.
751: 
752: danger
753: 
754: When using globs and moon hydrates an output (a cache hit), all files not matching the glob will be
755: deleted. Ensure that all files critical for the build to function correctly are included.
756: 
757: ### `preset`v1.28.0
758: 
759: Applies the chosen preset to the task. A preset defines a collection of task options that will be
760: inherited as the default, and can then be overridden within the task itself. The following presets
761: are available:
762: 
763: - `server` [`cache`](#cache) -> Turned off
764: 
765: - [`outputStyle`](#outputstyle) -> Set to "stream"
766: 
767: - [`persistent`](#persistent) -> Turned on
768: 
769: - [`runInCI`](#runinci) -> Turned off
770: 
771: - `utility` v2.0.0 [`cache`](#cache) -> Turned off
772: 
773: - [`interactive`](#interactive) -> Turned on
774: 
775: - [`outputStyle`](#outputstyle) -> Set to "stream"
776: 
777: - [`persistent`](#persistent) -> Turned off
778: 
779: - [`runInCI`](#runinci) -> Skipped
780: 
781: Tasks named "dev", "start", or "serve" are marked as `server` automatically.
782: 
783: moon.yml
784: 
785: ```
786: tasks:  dev:    command: 'webpack server'    preset: 'server'
787: ```
788: 
789: ### `script`v1.27.0
790: 
791: The `script` field is one or many commands to execute for the task, with support for pipes,
792: redirects, and more. This field does not support task inheritance merging, and can only be defined
793: with a string.
794: 
795: If defined, will supersede [`command`](#command) and [`args`](#args).
796: 
797: moon.yml
798: 
799: ```
800: tasks:  exec:    # Single command    script: 'cp ./in ./out'    # Multiple commands    script: 'rm -rf ./out && cp ./in ./out'    # Pipes    script: 'ps aux | grep 3000'    # Redirects    script: './gen.sh > out.json'
801: ```
802: 
803: info
804: 
805: If you need to support merging during task inheritance, use [`command`](#command) instead. Learn
806: more about [commands vs scripts](/docs/concepts/task#commands-vs-scripts).
807: 
808: ### `toolchains`v1.31.0
809: 
810: The `toolchain` field defines additional [toolchain(s)](/docs/concepts/toolchain) the command runs on,
811: where to locate its executable, and more. By default, moon will set to a value based on the
812: project's [`language`](#language), default [`toolchain.default`](#toolchain-1), or via detection.
813: 
814: moon.yml
815: 
816: ```
817: tasks:  env:    command: 'printenv'    toolchains: 'system'
818: ```
819: 
820: This setting also supports multiple values.
821: 
822: moon.yml
823: 
824: ```
825: tasks:  build:    command: 'npm run build'    toolchains: ['javascript', 'node', 'npm']
826: ```
827: 
828: ### `options`
829: 
830: The `options` field is an object of configurable options that can be used to modify the task and its
831: execution. The following fields can be provided, with merge related fields supporting all
832: [merge strategies](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance#merge-strategies).
833: 
834: moon.yml
835: 
836: ```
837: tasks:  typecheck:    command: 'tsc --noEmit'    options:      mergeArgs: 'replace'      runFromWorkspaceRoot: true
838: ```
839: 
840: #### `affectedFiles`
841: 
842: When enabled and the [`--affected` option](/docs/run-task#running-based-on-affected-files-only) is
843: provided, all affected files that match this task's [`inputs`](#inputs) will be passed as relative
844: file paths as command line arguments, and as a `MOON_AFFECTED_FILES` environment variable.
845: 
846: If there are no affected files, `.` (current directory) will be passed instead for arguments, and an
847: empty value for the environment variable. This functionality can be changed with the
848: [`affectedPassInputs`](#affectedpassinputs) setting.
849: 
850: moon.yml
851: 
852: ```
853: tasks:  lint:    command: 'eslint'    options:      affectedFiles: true      # Only pass args      affectedFiles: 'args'      # Only set env var      affectedFiles: 'env'
854: ```
855: 
856: caution
857: 
858: When using this option, ensure that explicit files or `.` are not present in the [`args`](#args)
859: list. Furthermore, this functionality will only work if the task's command supports an arbitrary
860: list of files being passed as arguments.
861: 
862: This setting also supports an object format with additional parameters. The `pass` field is
863: required, which accepts a value described above.
864: 
865: moon.yml
866: 
867: ```
868: tasks:  lint:    command: 'eslint'    options:      affectedFiles:        pass: 'args'
869: ```
870: 
871: The following additional parameters are supported:
872: 
873: - `passInputsWhenNoMatch` (`boolean`) - When no affected files are found, and `pass` includes `args`, will pass all configured [`inputs`](#inputs) as relative file paths instead of `.`. Defaults to `false`.
874: 
875: #### `allowFailure`v1.13.0
876: 
877: Allows a task to fail without failing the entire pipeline. When enabled, the following changes
878: occur:
879: 
880: - Other tasks cannot depend on this task, as we can't ensure it's side-effect free.
881: 
882: - For [`moon run`](/docs/commands/run), the process will not bail early and will run to completion.
883: 
884: - For [`moon ci`](/docs/commands/ci), the process will not exit with a non-zero exit code, if the only failing tasks are allowed to fail.
885: 
886: moon.yml
887: 
888: ```
889: tasks:  lint:    command: 'eslint'    options:      allowFailure: true
890: ```
891: 
892: #### `cache`
893: 
894: Whether to cache the task's execution result using our [smart hashing](/docs/concepts/cache#hashing)
895: system. If disabled, will not create a cache hash, and will not persist a task's
896: [outputs](#outputs). Supports the following values:
897: 
898: - `true` (default) - Cache the task's output.
899: 
900: - `false` - Do not cache the task's output.
901: 
902: - `local` - Only cache locally. v1.40.0
903: 
904: - `remote` - Only cache [remotely](/docs/guides/remote-cache). v1.40.0
905: 
906: We suggest disabling caching when defining cleanup tasks, one-off scripts, or file system heavy
907: operations.
908: 
909: moon.yml
910: 
911: ```
912: tasks:  clean:    command: 'rm -rf ./temp'    options:      cache: false
913: ```
914: 
915: #### `cacheKey`v1.35.0
916: 
917: A custom key to include in the cache and task hashing process. Can be used to invalidate local and
918: remote caches.
919: 
920: moon.yml
921: 
922: ```
923: tasks:  build:    command: 'some-costly-build'    options:      cacheKey: 'v1'
924: ```
925: 
926: #### `cacheLifetime`v1.29.0
927: 
928: The lifetime in which a [cached task](#cache) will live before being marked as stale and re-running.
929: This applies to a task even if it does not produce [outputs](#outputs).
930: 
931: The lifetime can be configured in a human-readable string format, for example, `1 day`, `3 hr`,
932: `1m`, etc. If the lifetime is not defined, the cache will live forever, or until the task inputs are
933: touched.
934: 
935: moon.yml
936: 
937: ```
938: tasks:  build:    command: 'some-costly-build'    options:      cacheLifetime: '1 day'
939: ```
940: 
941: String formats are powered by the
942: [humantime](https://docs.rs/humantime/2.1.0/humantime/fn.parse_duration.html) crate.
943: 
944: #### `envFile`
945: 
946: A boolean or path to a `.env` file (also know as dotenv file) that defines a collection of
947: [environment variables](#env-1) for the current task. Variables will be loaded on project creation,
948: but will not override those defined in [`env`](#env-1).
949: 
950: Variables defined in the file support value substitution/expansion by wrapping the variable name in
951: curly brackets, such as `${VAR_NAME}`.
952: 
953: moon.yml
954: 
955: ```
956: tasks:  build:    command: 'webpack'    options:      # Defaults to .env      envFile: true      # Or      envFile: '.env.production'      # Or from the workspace root      envFile: '/.env.shared'
957: ```
958: 
959: When set to `true`, moon will load the following files in order, with later files taking precedence
960: over earlier ones:
961: 
962: - `/.env`
963: 
964: - `/.env.local`
965: 
966: - `.env`
967: 
968: - `.env.local`
969: 
970: - `.env.`
971: 
972: - `.env..local`
973: 
974: Additionally, a list of file paths can also be provided. When using a list, the order of the files
975: is important, as environment variables from all files will be aggregated into a single map, with
976: subsequent files taking precedence over previous ones. Once aggregated, the variables will be passed
977: to the task, but will not override those defined in [`env`](#env-1).
978: 
979: moon.yml
980: 
981: ```
982: tasks:  build:    command: 'webpack'    options:      envFile:        - '.env'        - '.env.production'
983: ```
984: 
985: #### `inferInputs`v1.31.0
986: 
987: Automatically infer [inputs](#inputs) based on the following parameters configured within the task's
988: `command`, `script`, `args`, or `env`. Defaults to `false`.
989: 
990: - File/glob paths derived from [file group based token functions](/docs/concepts/token#file-groups).
991: 
992: - Environment variables being substituted within a command or script.
993: 
994: moon.yml
995: 
996: ```
997: tasks:  build:    # ...    options:      inferInputs: false
998: ```
999: 
1000: #### `internal`v1.23.0
1001: 
1002: Marks the task as internal only. [Internal tasks](/docs/concepts/task#internal-only) can not be
1003: explicitly ran on the command line, but can be depended on by other tasks.
1004: 
1005: moon.yml
1006: 
1007: ```
1008: tasks:  prepare:    # ...    options:      internal: true
1009: ```
1010: 
1011: #### `interactive`v1.12.0
1012: 
1013: Marks the task as interactive. [Interactive tasks](/docs/concepts/task#interactive) run in isolation so
1014: that they can interact with stdin.
1015: 
1016: This setting also disables caching, turns of CI, and other functionality, similar to the
1017: [`preset`](#preset) setting.
1018: 
1019: moon.yml
1020: 
1021: ```
1022: tasks:  init:    # ...    options:      interactive: true
1023: ```
1024: 
1025: #### `merge`v1.29.0
1026: 
1027: The [strategy](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance#merge-strategies) to use when merging [`args`](#args),
1028: [`deps`](#deps), [`env`](#env-1), [`inputs`](#inputs), and [`outputs`](#outputs) with an inherited
1029: task. This option can be overridden with the field specific merge options below.
1030: 
1031: #### `mergeArgs`
1032: 
1033: The [strategy](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance#merge-strategies) to use when merging the
1034: [`args`](#args) list with an inherited task. Defaults to "append".
1035: 
1036: #### `mergeDeps`
1037: 
1038: The [strategy](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance#merge-strategies) to use when merging the
1039: [`deps`](#deps) list with an inherited task. Defaults to "append".
1040: 
1041: #### `mergeEnv`
1042: 
1043: The [strategy](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance#merge-strategies) to use when merging the
1044: [`env`](#env-1) map with an inherited task. Defaults to "append".
1045: 
1046: #### `mergeInputs`
1047: 
1048: The [strategy](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance#merge-strategies) to use when merging the
1049: [`inputs`](#inputs) list with an inherited task. Defaults to "append".
1050: 
1051: #### `mergeOutputs`
1052: 
1053: The [strategy](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance#merge-strategies) to use when merging the
1054: [`outputs`](#outputs) list with an inherited task. Defaults to "append".
1055: 
1056: #### `mergeToolchains`
1057: 
1058: The [strategy](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance#merge-strategies) to use when merging the
1059: [`toolchains`](#toolchains) list with an inherited task. Defaults to "append".
1060: 
1061: #### `mutex`v1.24.0
1062: 
1063: Creates an exclusive lock on a "virtual resource", preventing other tasks using the same "virtual
1064: resource" from running concurrently.
1065: 
1066: If you have many tasks that require exclusive access to a resource that can't be tracked by moon
1067: (like a database, an ignored file, a file that's not part of the project, or a remote resource) you
1068: can use the `mutex` option to prevent them from running at the same time.
1069: 
1070: moon.yml
1071: 
1072: ```
1073: tasks:  a:    # ...    options:      mutex: 'virtual_resource_name'  # b doesn't necessarily have to be in the same project  b:    # ...    options:      mutex: 'virtual_resource_name'
1074: ```
1075: 
1076: #### `os`v1.28.0
1077: 
1078: When defined, the task will only run on the configured operating system. For other operating
1079: systems, the task becomes a no-operation. Supports the values `linux`, `macos`, and `windows`.
1080: 
1081: Can be defined as a single value, or a list of values.
1082: 
1083: moon.yml
1084: 
1085: ```
1086: tasks:  build-unix:    # ...    options:      os: ['linux', 'macos']  build-windows:    # ...    options:      os: 'windows'
1087: ```
1088: 
1089: #### `outputStyle`
1090: 
1091: Controls how stdout/stderr is displayed when the task is ran as a transitive target. By default,
1092: this setting is not defined and defers to the action pipeline, but can be overridden with one of the
1093: following values:
1094: 
1095: - `buffer` - Buffers output and displays after the task has exited (either success or failure).
1096: 
1097: - `buffer-only-failure` - Like `buffer`, but only displays on failures.
1098: 
1099: - `hash` - Ignores output and only displays the generated [hash](/docs/concepts/cache#hashing).
1100: 
1101: - `none` - Ignores output.
1102: 
1103: - `stream` - Streams output directly to the terminal. Will prefix each line of output with the target.
1104: 
1105: moon.yml
1106: 
1107: ```
1108: tasks:  test:    # ...    options:      outputStyle: 'stream'
1109: ```
1110: 
1111: #### `persistent`v1.6.0
1112: 
1113: Marks the task as persistent (continuously running). [Persistent tasks](/docs/concepts/task#persistent)
1114: are handled differently than non-persistent tasks in the action graph. When running a target, all
1115: persistent tasks are ran last and in parallel, after all their dependencies have completed.
1116: 
1117: This is extremely useful for running a server (or a watcher) in the background while other tasks are
1118: running.
1119: 
1120: moon.yml
1121: 
1122: ```
1123: tasks:  dev:    # ...    options:      persistent: true
1124: ```
1125: 
1126: We suggest using the [`preset`](#preset) setting instead, which enables this setting, amongst
1127: other useful settings.
1128: 
1129: #### `priority`v1.35.0
1130: 
1131: The priority level determines the position of the task within the action pipeline queue. A task with
1132: a higher priority will run sooner rather than later, while still respecting the topological order.
1133: Supports the following levels:
1134: 
1135: - `critical`
1136: 
1137: - `high`
1138: 
1139: - `normal` (default)
1140: 
1141: - `low`
1142: 
1143: moon.yml
1144: 
1145: ```
1146: tasks:  build:    # ...    options:      priority: 'high'
1147: ```
1148: 
1149: #### `retryCount`
1150: 
1151: The number of attempts the task will retry execution before returning a failure. This is especially
1152: useful for flaky tasks. Defaults to `0`.
1153: 
1154: moon.yml
1155: 
1156: ```
1157: tasks:  test:    # ...    options:      retryCount: 3
1158: ```
1159: 
1160: #### `runDepsInParallel`
1161: 
1162: Whether to run the task's direct [`deps`](#deps) in parallel or serial (in order). Defaults to
1163: `true`.
1164: 
1165: When disabled, this does not run dependencies of dependencies in serial, only direct dependencies.
1166: 
1167: moon.yml
1168: 
1169: ```
1170: tasks:  start:    # ...    deps:      - '~:clean'      - '~:build'    options:      runDepsInParallel: false
1171: ```
1172: 
1173: #### `runInCI`
1174: 
1175: Whether to run the task automatically in a CI (continuous integration) environment when affected by
1176: touched files using the [`moon ci`](/docs/commands/ci) command. Supports the following values:
1177: 
1178: - `always` - Always run in CI, regardless if affected or not. v1.31.0
1179: 
1180: - `affected`, `true` (default) - Only run in CI if affected by touched files.
1181: 
1182: - `false` - Never run in CI.
1183: 
1184: - `only` - Only run in CI, and not locally, if affected by touched files. v1.41.0
1185: 
1186: - `skip` - Skip running in CI but run locally and allow task relationships to be valid. v1.41.0
1187: 
1188: moon.yml
1189: 
1190: ```
1191: tasks:  build:    # ...    options:      runInCI: false
1192: ```
1193: 
1194: #### `runFromWorkspaceRoot`
1195: 
1196: Whether to use the workspace root as the working directory when executing a task. Defaults to
1197: `false` and runs from the task's project root.
1198: 
1199: moon.yml
1200: 
1201: ```
1202: tasks:  typecheck:    # ...    options:      runFromWorkspaceRoot: true
1203: ```
1204: 
1205: #### `shell`
1206: 
1207: Whether to run the command within a shell or not. Defaults to `true` for system toolchain or
1208: Windows, and `false` otherwise. The shell to run is determined by the [`unixShell`](#unixshell) and
1209: [`windowsShell`](#windowsshell) options respectively.
1210: 
1211: moon.yml
1212: 
1213: ```
1214: tasks:  native:    command: 'echo $SHELL'    options:      shell: true
1215: ```
1216: 
1217: However, if you'd like to use a different shell, or customize the shell's arguments, or have
1218: granular control, you can set `shell` to false and configure a fully qualified command.
1219: 
1220: moon.yml
1221: 
1222: ```
1223: tasks:  native:    command: '/bin/zsh -c "echo $SHELL"'    options:      shell: false
1224: ```
1225: 
1226: #### `timeout`v1.26.0
1227: 
1228: The maximum time in seconds that the task is allowed to run, before it is force cancelled. If not
1229: defined, will run indefinitely.
1230: 
1231: moon.yml
1232: 
1233: ```
1234: tasks:  build:    # ...    options:      timeout: 120
1235: ```
1236: 
1237: #### `unixShell`v1.21.0
1238: 
1239: Customize the shell to run with when on a Unix operating system. Accepts `bash`, `elvish`, `fish`,
1240: `ion`, `murex`, `nu`, `pwsh`, `xonsh`, or `zsh`. If not defined, will derive the shell from the
1241: `SHELL` environment variable, or defaults to `bash`.
1242: 
1243: moon.yml
1244: 
1245: ```
1246: tasks:  native:    command: 'echo $SHELL'    options:      unixShell: 'fish'
1247: ```
1248: 
1249: #### `windowsShell`v1.21.0
1250: 
1251: Customize the shell to run with when on a Windows operating system. Accepts `bash` (typically via
1252: Git), `elvish`, `fish`, `murex`, `nu`, `pwsh`, or `xonsh`. If not defined, defaults to `pwsh`.
1253: 
1254: moon.yml
1255: 
1256: ```
1257: tasks:  native:    command: 'echo $SHELL'    options:      windowsShell: 'bash'
1258: ```
1259: 
1260: ## Overrides
1261: 
1262: Dictates how a project interacts with settings defined at the top-level.
1263: 
1264: ## `toolchains`
1265: 
1266: ### `default`v1.31.0
1267: 
1268: The default [`toolchain`](#toolchain-1) for all task's within the current project. When a task's
1269: `toolchain` has not been explicitly configured, the toolchain will fallback to this configured
1270: value, otherwise the toolchain will be detected from the project's environment.
1271: 
1272: moon.yml
1273: 
1274: ```
1275: toolchains:  default: 'node'
1276: ```
1277: 
1278: ### `bun`
1279: 
1280: Configures Bun for this project and overrides the top-level [`bun`](/docs/config/toolchain#bun) setting.
1281: 
1282: #### `version`
1283: 
1284: Defines the explicit Bun [version specification](/docs/concepts/toolchain#version-specification) to use
1285: when running tasks for this project.
1286: 
1287: moon.yml
1288: 
1289: ```
1290: toolchains:  bun:    version: '1.0.0'
1291: ```
1292: 
1293: ### `deno`
1294: 
1295: Configures Deno for this project and overrides the top-level [`deno`](/docs/config/toolchain#deno) setting.
1296: 
1297: #### `version`
1298: 
1299: Defines the explicit Deno [version specification](/docs/concepts/toolchain#version-specification) to
1300: use when running tasks for this project.
1301: 
1302: moon.yml
1303: 
1304: ```
1305: toolchains:  deno:    version: '1.40.0'
1306: ```
1307: 
1308: ### `node`
1309: 
1310: Configures Node.js for this project and overrides the top-level [`node`](/docs/config/toolchain#node) setting.
1311: Currently, only the Node.js version can be overridden per-project, not the package manager.
1312: 
1313: #### `version`
1314: 
1315: Defines the explicit Node.js [version specification](/docs/concepts/toolchain#version-specification) to
1316: use when running tasks for this project.
1317: 
1318: moon.yml
1319: 
1320: ```
1321: toolchains:  node:    version: '12.12.0'
1322: ```
1323: 
1324: ### `python`
1325: 
1326: Configures Python for this project and overrides the top-level [`python`](/docs/config/toolchain#python)
1327: setting.
1328: 
1329: #### `version`
1330: 
1331: Defines the explicit Python
1332: [version/channel specification](/docs/concepts/toolchain#version-specification) to use when running
1333: tasks for this project.
1334: 
1335: moon.yml
1336: 
1337: ```
1338: toolchains:  python:    version: '3.12.0'
1339: ```
1340: 
1341: ### `rust`
1342: 
1343: Configures Rust for this project and overrides the top-level [`rust`](/docs/config/toolchain#rust) setting.
1344: 
1345: #### `version`
1346: 
1347: Defines the explicit Rust
1348: [version/channel specification](/docs/concepts/toolchain#version-specification) to use when running
1349: tasks for this project.
1350: 
1351: moon.yml
1352: 
1353: ```
1354: toolchains:  rust:    version: '1.68.0'
1355: ```
1356: 
1357: ### `typescript`
1358: 
1359: #### `includeProjectReferenceSources`v1.17.0
1360: 
1361: Overrides the workspace-level
1362: [`includeProjectReferenceSources`](/docs/config/toolchain#includeprojectreferencesources) setting. Defaults to
1363: undefined.
1364: 
1365: moon.yml
1366: 
1367: ```
1368: toolchains:  typescript:    includeProjectReferenceSources: false
1369: ```
1370: 
1371: #### `includeSharedTypes`v1.17.0
1372: 
1373: Overrides the workspace-level [`includeSharedTypes`](/docs/config/toolchain#includesharedtypes) setting.
1374: Defaults to undefined.
1375: 
1376: moon.yml
1377: 
1378: ```
1379: toolchains:  typescript:    includeSharedTypes: false
1380: ```
1381: 
1382: #### `routeOutDirToCache`
1383: 
1384: Overrides the workspace-level [`routeOutDirToCache`](/docs/config/toolchain#routeoutdirtocache) setting.
1385: Defaults to undefined.
1386: 
1387: moon.yml
1388: 
1389: ```
1390: toolchains:  typescript:    routeOutDirToCache: false
1391: ```
1392: 
1393: #### `syncProjectReferences`
1394: 
1395: Overrides the workspace-level [`syncProjectReferences`](/docs/config/toolchain#syncprojectreferences) setting.
1396: Defaults to undefined.
1397: 
1398: moon.yml
1399: 
1400: ```
1401: toolchains:  typescript:    syncProjectReferences: false
1402: ```
1403: 
1404: #### `syncProjectReferencesToPaths`
1405: 
1406: Overrides the workspace-level
1407: [`syncProjectReferencesToPaths`](/docs/config/toolchain#syncprojectreferencestopaths) setting. Defaults to
1408: undefined.
1409: 
1410: moon.yml
1411: 
1412: ```
1413: toolchains:  typescript:    syncProjectReferencesToPaths: false
1414: ```
1415: 
1416: ## `workspace`
1417: 
1418: ### `inheritedTasks`
1419: 
1420: Provides a layer of control when inheriting tasks from [`.moon/tasks/all.yml`](/docs/config/tasks).
1421: 
1422: #### `exclude`
1423: 
1424: The optional `exclude` setting permits a project to exclude specific tasks from being inherited. It
1425: accepts a list of strings, where each string is the name of a global task to exclude.
1426: 
1427: moon.yml
1428: 
1429: ```
1430: workspace:  inheritedTasks:    # Exclude the inherited `test` task for this project    exclude: ['test']
1431: ```
1432: 
1433: Exclusion is applied after inclusion and before renaming.
1434: 
1435: #### `include`
1436: 
1437: The optional `include` setting permits a project to only include specific inherited tasks (works
1438: like an allow/white list). It accepts a list of strings, where each string is the name of a global
1439: task to include.
1440: 
1441: When this field is not defined, the project will inherit all tasks from the global project config.
1442: 
1443: moon.yml
1444: 
1445: ```
1446: workspace:  inheritedTasks:    # Include *no* tasks (works like a full exclude)    include: []    # Only include the `lint` and `test` tasks for this project    include:      - 'lint'      - 'test'
1447: ```
1448: 
1449: Inclusion is applied before exclusion and renaming.
1450: 
1451: #### `rename`
1452: 
1453: The optional `rename` setting permits a project to rename the inherited task within the current
1454: project. It accepts a map of strings, where the key is the original name (found in the global
1455: project config), and the value is the new name to use.
1456: 
1457: For example, say we have 2 tasks in the global project config called `buildPackage` and
1458: `buildApplication`, but we only need 1, and since we're an application, we should omit and rename.
1459: 
1460: moon.yml
1461: 
1462: ```
1463: workspace:  inheritedTasks:    exclude: ['buildPackage']    rename:      buildApplication: 'build'
1464: ```
1465: 
1466: Renaming occurs after inclusion and exclusion.
1467: 
1468: ----
1469: ## Notes / Comments / Lessons
1470: 
1471: - Collection method: sitemap discovery + markdown conversion.
1472: - Conversion path: direct HTML fallback parser.
1473: - This file is one page-level external snapshot in markdown `.ext.md` format.
1474: ----
1475: 

(End of file - total 1475 lines)
</content>

Source: https://moonrepo.dev/docs/config/project

# moon

The `moon.yml` configuration file is not required but can be used to define additional metadata
for a project, override inherited tasks, and more at the project-level. When used, this file must
exist in a project's root, as configured in [`projects`](/docs/config/workspace#projects).

## `dependsOn`

<content>1: ----
2: ## External Docs Snapshot // moonrepo
3: 
4: - Captured: 2026-02-16T03:48:02.472Z
5: - Source root: https://moonrepo.dev/docs
6: - Source page: /docs/config/tasks
7: - Keywords: moon, moonrepo, docs, monorepo, build, config, tasks
8: - Summary: The `.moon/tasks/**/*` files configures file groups and tasks that are inherited by every project
9: ----
10: 
11: Source: https://moonrepo.dev/docs/config/tasks
12: 
13: # .moon/tasks
14: 
15: The `.moon/tasks/**/*` files configures file groups and tasks that are inherited by every project
16: in the workspace based on inheritance conditions.
17: [Learn more about task inheritance!](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance)
18: 
19: Projects can override or merge with these settings within their respective [`moon.yml`](/docs/config/project).
20: 
21: ## `extends`
22: 
23: Defines one or many external `.moon/tasks/all.yml`'s to extend and inherit settings from. Perfect
24: for reusability and sharing configuration across repositories and projects. When defined, this
25: setting must be an HTTPS URL or relative file system path that points to a valid YAML document!
26: 
27: .moon/tasks/all.yml
28: 
29: ```
30: extends: 'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/organization/repository/master/.moon/tasks/all.yml'
31: ```
32: 
33: caution
34: 
35: For map-based settings, `fileGroups` and `tasks`, entries from both the extended configuration and
36: local configuration are merged into a new map, with the values of the local taking precedence. Map
37: values are not deep merged!
38: 
39: ## `fileGroups`
40: 
41: For more information on file group configuration, refer to the
42: [`fileGroups`](/docs/config/project#filegroups) section in the [`moon.yml`](/docs/config/project) doc.
43: 
44: Defines [file groups](/docs/concepts/file-group) that will be inherited by projects, and also enables
45: enforcement of organizational patterns and file locations. For example, encourage projects to place
46: source files in a `src` folder, and all test files in `tests`.
47: 
48: .moon/tasks/all.yml
49: 
50: ```
51: fileGroups:  configs:    - '*.config.{js,cjs,mjs}'    - '*.json'  sources:    - 'src/**/*'    - 'types/**/*'  tests:    - 'tests/**/*'    - '**/__tests__/**/*'  assets:    - 'assets/**/*'    - 'images/**/*'    - 'static/**/*'    - '**/*.{scss,css}'
52: ```
53: 
54: info
55: 
56: File paths and globs used within a file group are relative from the inherited project's root, and
57: not the workspace root.
58: 
59: ## `implicitDeps`
60: 
61: Defines task [`deps`](/docs/config/project#deps) that are implicitly inserted into all inherited tasks within
62: a project. This is extremely useful for pre-building projects that are used extensively throughout
63: the repo, or always building project dependencies. Defaults to an empty list.
64: 
65: .moon/tasks/all.yml
66: 
67: ```
68: implicitDeps:  - '^:build'
69: ```
70: 
71: info
72: 
73: Implicit dependencies are always inherited, regardless of the [`mergeDeps`](/docs/config/project#mergedeps)
74: option.
75: 
76: ## `implicitInputs`
77: 
78: Defines task [`inputs`](/docs/config/project#inputs) that are implicitly inserted into all inherited tasks
79: within a project. This is extremely useful for the "changes to these files should always trigger a
80: task" scenario.
81: 
82: Like `inputs`, file paths/globs defined here are relative from the inheriting project.
83: [Project and workspace relative file patterns](/docs/concepts/file-pattern#project-relative) are
84: supported and encouraged.
85: 
86: .moon/tasks/node.yml
87: 
88: ```
89: implicitInputs:  - 'package.json'
90: ```
91: 
92: info
93: 
94: Implicit inputs are always inherited, regardless of the [`mergeInputs`](/docs/config/project#mergeinputs)
95: option.
96: 
97: ## `inheritedBy`v2.0.0
98: 
99: A map of conditions that must be met for the configuration within the file to be inherited by a
100: project. When this field is not defined, or is an empty map, the configuration will be inherited by
101: all projects.
102: 
103: .moon/tasks/custom.yml
104: 
105: ```
106: inheritedBy:  # Project belongs to either javascript or typescript toolchain, but not the ruby toolchain  toolchains:    or: ['javascript', 'typescript']    not: ['ruby']  # And project is either a frontend or backend stack  stacks: ['frontend', 'backend']  # And project is either a library or tool layer  layers: ['library', 'tool']
107: ```
108: 
109: info
110: 
111: View the [official task inheritance guide](/docs/concepts/task-inheritance) for more information!
112: 
113: ## `tasks`
114: 
115: For more information on task configuration, refer to the [`tasks`](/docs/config/project#tasks) section in the
116: [`moon.yml`](/docs/config/project) doc.
117: 
118: As mentioned in the link above, [tasks](/docs/concepts/task) are actions that are ran within the
119: context of a project, and commonly wrap a command. For most workspaces, every project should have
120: linting, typechecking, testing, code formatting, so on and so forth. To reduce the amount of
121: boilerplate that every project would require, this setting offers the ability to define tasks that
122: are inherited by many projects within the workspace, but can also be overridden per project.
123: 
124: .moon/tasks/all.yml
125: 
126: ```
127: tasks:  format:    command: 'prettier --check .'  lint:    command: 'eslint --no-error-on-unmatched-pattern .'  test:    command: 'jest --passWithNoTests'  typecheck:    command: 'tsc --build'
128: ```
129: 
130: info
131: 
132: Relative file paths and globs used within a task are relative from the inherited project's root, and
133: not the workspace root.
134: 
135: ## `taskOptions`v1.20.0
136: 
137: For more information on task options, refer to the [`options`](/docs/config/project#options) section in the
138: [`moon.yml`](/docs/config/project) doc.
139: 
140: Like [tasks](#tasks), this setting allows you to define task options that will be inherited by all
141: tasks within the configured file, and by all project-level inherited tasks. This setting is the 1st
142: link in the inheritance chain, and can be overridden within each task.
143: 
144: .moon/tasks/all.yml
145: 
146: ```
147: taskOptions:  # Never cache builds  cache: false  # Always re-run flaky tests  retryCount: 2tasks:  build:    # ...    options:      # Override the default cache setting      cache: true
148: ```
149: 
150: ----
151: ## Notes / Comments / Lessons
152: 
153: - Collection method: sitemap discovery + markdown conversion.
154: - Conversion path: direct HTML fallback parser.
155: - This file is one page-level external snapshot in markdown `.ext.md` format.

<content>1: ----
2: ## External Docs Snapshot // moonrepo
3: 
4: - Captured: 2026-02-16T03:48:02.472Z
5: - Source root: https://moonrepo.dev/docs
6: - Source page: /docs/guides/javascript/bun-handbook
7: - Keywords: moon, moonrepo, docs, monorepo, build, guides, javascript, bun handbook
8: - Summary: Utilizing JavaScript (and TypeScript) in a monorepo can be a daunting task, especially when using
9: ----
10: 
11: Source: https://moonrepo.dev/docs/guides/javascript/bun-handbook
12: 
13: # Bun handbook
14: 
15: Utilizing JavaScript (and TypeScript) in a monorepo can be a daunting task, especially when using
16: Bun (or Node.js), as there are many ways to structure your code and to configure your tools. With
17: this handbook, we'll help guide you through this process.
18: 
19: info
20: 
21: This guide is a living document and will continue to be updated over time!
22: 
23: ## moon setup
24: 
25: For this part of the handbook, we'll be focusing on [moon](/moon), our task runner. To start,
26: languages in moon act like plugins, where their functionality and support is not enabled unless
27: explicitly configured. We follow this approach to avoid unnecessary overhead.
28: 
29: ### Enabling the language
30: 
31: To enable JavaScript support via Bun, define the [`bun`](/docs/config/toolchain#bun) setting in
32: [`.moon/toolchains.yml`](/docs/config/toolchain), even if an empty object.
33: 
34: .moon/toolchains.yml
35: 
36: ```
37: # Enable Bunbun: {}
38: ```
39: 
40: info
41: 
42: In moon v1.40+, use `javascript` and `bun` instead of `bun` to enable the new WASM powered Bun
43: toolchain, which is far more accurate and efficient. The non-WASM toolchain will be deprecated in
44: the future.
45: 
46: Or by pinning a `bun` version in [`.prototools`](/docs/proto/config) in the workspace root.
47: 
48: .prototools
49: 
50: ```
51: bun = "1.0.0"
52: ```
53: 
54: This will enable the Bun toolchain and provide the following automations around its ecosystem:
55: 
56: - Node modules will automatically be installed if dependencies in `package.json` have changed, or the lockfile has changed, since the last time a task has ran. We'll also take `package.json` workspaces into account and install modules in the correct location; either the workspace root, in a project, or both.
57: 
58: - Relationships between projects will automatically be discovered based on `dependencies`, `devDependencies`, and `peerDependencies` in `package.json`.
59: 
60: ### Utilizing the toolchain
61: 
62: When a language is enabled, moon by default will assume that the language's binary is available
63: within the current environment (typically on `PATH`). This has the downside of requiring all
64: developers and machines to manually install the correct version of the language, and to stay in
65: sync.
66: 
67: Instead, you can utilize [moon's toolchain](/docs/concepts/toolchain), which will download and
68: install the language in the background, and ensure every task is executed using the exact version
69: across all machines.
70: 
71: Enabling the toolchain is as simple as defining the [`bun.version`](/docs/config/toolchain#version)
72: setting.
73: 
74: .moon/toolchains.yml
75: 
76: ```
77: # Enable Bun toolchain with an explicit versionbun:  version: '1.0.0'
78: ```
79: 
80: Versions can also be defined with [`.prototools`](/docs/proto/config).
81: 
82: ### Configuring the toolchain
83: 
84: Since the JavaScript ecosystem supports multiple runtimes, moon is unable to automatically detect
85: the correct runtime for all scenarios. Does the existence of a `package.json` mean Node.js or Bun?
86: We don't know, and default to Node.js because of its popularity.
87: 
88: To work around this, you can set `toolchain` to "bun" at the task-level or project-level.
89: 
90: moon.yml
91: 
92: ```
93: # For all tasks in the projecttoolchain:  default: 'bun'tasks:  build:    command: 'webpack'    # For this specific task    toolchain: 'bun'
94: ```
95: 
96: The task-level `toolchain.default` only needs to be set if executing a `node_modules` binary! The
97: `bun` binary automatically sets the toolchain to Bun.
98: 
99: ### Using `package.json` scripts
100: 
101: If you're looking to prototype moon, or reduce the migration effort to moon tasks, you can configure
102: moon to inherit `package.json` scripts, and internally convert them to moon tasks. This can be
103: achieved with the [`bun.inferTasksFromScripts`](/docs/config/toolchain#infertasksfromscripts)
104: setting.
105: 
106: .moon/toolchains.yml
107: 
108: ```
109: bun:  inferTasksFromScripts: true
110: ```
111: 
112: Or you can run scripts through `bun run` calls.
113: 
114: moon.yml
115: 
116: ```
117: tasks:  build:    command: 'bun run build'
118: ```
119: 
120: ## Handbook
121: 
122: info
123: 
124: Refer to the [Node.js handbook](/docs/guides/javascript/node-handbook) for more information on repository structure,
125: dependency management, and more. Since both runtimes are extremely similar, the information in that
126: handbook also applies to Bun!
127: 
128: ----
129: ## Notes / Comments / Lessons
130: 
131: - Collection method: sitemap discovery + markdown conversion.
132: - Conversion path: direct HTML fallback parser.
133: - This file is one page-level external snapshot in markdown `.ext.md` format.
134: ----
135: 

(End of file - total 135 lines)
</content>

7: - Keywords: moon, moonrepo, docs, monorepo, build, commands, run
8: - Summary: The `moon run` (or `moon r`) command will run one or many [targets](/docs/concepts/target) and all of
9: ----
10: 
11: Source: https://moonrepo.dev/docs/commands/run
12: 
13: # run
14: 
15: The `moon run` (or `moon r`) command will run one or many [targets](/docs/concepts/target) and all of
16: its dependencies in topological order. Each run will incrementally cache each task, improving speed
17: and development times... over time. View the official [Run a task](/docs/run-task) and
18: [Cheat sheet](/docs/cheat-sheet#tasks) articles for more information!
19: 
20: ```
21: # Run `lint` in project `app`$ moon run app:lint# Run `dev` in project `client` and `server`$ moon run client:dev server:dev# Run `test` in all projects$ moon run :test# Run `test` in all projects with tag `frontend`$ moon run '#frontend:test'# Run `format` in default project$ moon run format# Run `build` in projects matching the query$ moon run :build --query "language=javascript && projectLayer=library"
22: ```
23: 
24: info
25: 
26: The default behavior for `moon run` is to "fail fast", meaning that any failed task will immediately
27: abort execution of the entire action graph. Use `moon exec --on-failure continue` for alternative
28: behavior.
29: 
30: ### Arguments
31: 
32: - `...` - [Targets](/docs/concepts/target) or project relative tasks to run.
33: 
34: - `[-- ]` - Additional arguments to [pass to the underlying command](/docs/run-task#passing-arguments-to-the-underlying-command).
35: 
36: ### Options
37: 
38: Inherits all options from [`moon exec`](/docs/commands/exec) except for `--on-failure`.
39: 
40: ### Configuration
41: 
42: - [`projects`](/docs/config/workspace#projects) in `.moon/workspace.yml`
43: 
44: - [`tasks`](/docs/config/tasks#tasks) in `.moon/tasks/all.yml`
45: 
46: - [`tasks`](/docs/config/project#tasks) in `moon.yml`
47: 
48: ----
49: ## Notes / Comments / Lessons
50: 
51: - Collection method: sitemap discovery + markdown conversion.
52: - Conversion path: direct HTML fallback parser.
53: - This file is one page-level external snapshot in markdown `.ext.md` format.
54: ----
55: 

(End of file - total 55 lines)
</content>

<type>file</type>
<content>1: ----
2: ## External Docs Snapshot // moonrepo
3: 
4: - Captured: 2026-02-16T03:48:02.472Z
5: - Source root: https://moonrepo.dev/docs
6: - Source page: /docs/install
7: - Keywords: moon, moonrepo, docs, monorepo, build, install
8: - Summary: The following guide can be used to install moon and integrate it into an existing repository (with
9: ----
10: 
11: Source: https://moonrepo.dev/docs/install
12: 
13: # Install moon
14: 
15: 2 min
16: 
17: The following guide can be used to install moon and integrate it into an existing repository (with
18: or without incremental adoption), or to a fresh repository.
19: 
20: ## Installing
21: 
22: The entirety of moon is packaged and shipped as a single binary. It works on all major operating
23: systems, and does not require any external dependencies. For convenience, we provide the following
24: scripts to download and install moon.
25: 
26: ### proto
27: 
28: moon can be installed and managed in [proto's toolchain](/proto). This will install moon to
29: `~/.proto/tools/moon` and make the binary available at `~/.proto/bin`.
30: 
31: ```
32: proto install moon
33: ```
34: 
35: Furthermore, the version of moon can be pinned on a per-project basis using the
36: [`.prototools` config file](/docs/proto/config).
37: 
38: .prototools
39: 
40: ```
41: moon = "1.31.0"
42: ```
43: 
44: info
45: 
46: We suggest using proto to manage moon (and other tools), as it allows for multiple versions to be
47: installed and used. The other installation options only allow for a single version (typically the
48: last installed).
49: 
50: ### Linux, macOS, WSL
51: 
52: In a terminal that supports Bash, run:
53: 
54: ```
55: bash
56: info
57: 
58: If you are using Git Bash on Windows, you can run the [Unix commands](#linux-macos-wsl) above.
59: 
60: ### npm
61: 
62: moon is also packaged and shipped as a single binary through the
63: [`@moonrepo/cli`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@moonrepo/cli) npm package. Begin by installing this
64: package at the root of the repository.
65: 
66: - Yarn
67: - Yarn (classic)
68: - npm
69: - pnpm
70: - Bun
71: 
72: ```
73: yarn add --dev @moonrepo/cli
74: ```
75: 
76: ```
77: yarn add --dev @moonrepo/cli# If using workspacesyarn add --dev -W @moonrepo/cli
78: ```
79: 
80: ```
81: npm install --save-dev @moonrepo/cli
82: ```
83: 
84: ```
85: pnpm add --save-dev @moonrepo/cli# If using workspacespnpm add --save-dev -w @moonrepo/cli
86: ```
87: 
88: ```
89: bun install --dev @moonrepo/cli
90: ```
91: 
92: If you are installing with Bun, you'll need to add `@moonrepo/cli` as a
93: [trusted dependency](https://bun.sh/docs/install/lifecycle#trusteddependencies).
94: 
95: info
96: 
97: When a global `moon` binary is executed, and the `@moonrepo/cli` binary exists within the
98: repository, the npm package version will be executed instead. We do this because the npm package
99: denotes the exact version the repository is pinned it.
100: 
101: ### Other
102: 
103: moon can also be downloaded and installed manually, by downloading an asset from
104: [https://github.com/moonrepo/moon/releases](https://github.com/moonrepo/moon/releases). Be sure to
105: rename the file after downloading, and apply the executable bit (`chmod +x`) on macOS and Linux.
106: 
107: ## Upgrading
108: 
109: If using proto, moon can be upgraded using the following command:
110: 
111: ```
112: proto install moon --pin
113: ```
114: 
115: Otherwise, moon can be upgraded with the [`moon upgrade`](/docs/commands/upgrade) command. However, this
116: will only upgrade moon if it was installed in `~/.moon/bin`.
117: 
118: ```
119: moon upgrade
120: ```
121: 
122: Otherwise, you can re-run the installers above and it will download, install, and overwrite with the
123: latest version.
124: 
125: ## Canary releases
126: 
127: moon supports canary releases, which are built and published for every commit to our development
128: branches. These releases will include features and functionality that have not yet landed on master.
129: When using a canary release, you'll need to download and execute the binaries manually:
130: 
131: - Using our npm package [`@moonrepo/cli`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@moonrepo/cli?activeTab=versions) under the `canary` tag. Releases are versioned by date.
132: 
133: - From a [GitHub prerelease](https://github.com/moonrepo/moon/releases/tag/canary) using the `canary` tag. This tag always represents the latest development release.
134: 
135: ## Nightly releases
136: 
137: moon supports nightly releases, which are built and published once a day from the latest commit on
138: master. When using a nightly release, you'll need to download and execute the binaries manually.
139: 
140: - Using our npm package [`@moonrepo/cli`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@moonrepo/cli?activeTab=versions) under the `nightly` tag. Releases are versioned by date.
141: 
142: - From a [GitHub prerelease](https://github.com/moonrepo/moon/releases/tag/nightly) using the `nightly` tag. This tag always represents the latest stable release.
143: 
144: ## Next steps
145: 
146: [Setup workspace](/docs/setup-workspace)
147: 
148: ----
149: ## Notes / Comments / Lessons
150: 
151: - Collection method: sitemap discovery + markdown conversion.
152: - Conversion path: direct HTML fallback parser.
153: - This file is one page-level external snapshot in markdown `.ext.md` format.
154: ----
155:

</content>

2: ## External Docs Snapshot // moonrepo

4: - Captured: 2026-02-16T03:48:02.472Z
5: - Source root: https://moonrepo.dev/docs
6: - Source page: /docs/setup-toolchain
7: - Keywords: moon, moonrepo, docs, monorepo, build, setup toolchain
8: - Summary: One of moon's most powerful features is the [toolchain](/docs/concepts/toolchain), which automatically
9: ----
10: 
11: Source: https://moonrepo.dev/docs/setup-toolchain
12: 
13: # Setup toolchain
14: 
15: 5 min
16: 
17: One of moon's most powerful features is the [toolchain](/docs/concepts/toolchain), which automatically
18: manages, downloads, and installs Node.js and other languages behind the scenes using
19: [proto](/proto). It also enables [advanced functionality](/docs/how-it-works/languages#tier-2--platform)
20: for task running based on the platform (language and environment combination) it runs in.
21: 
22: The toolchain is configured with [`.moon/toolchains.yml`](/docs/config/toolchain).
23: 
24: tip
25: 
26: Change the language dropdown at the top right to switch the examples!
27: 
28: ## How it works
29: 
30: For more information on the toolchain, our tier based support, and how languages integrate into
31: moon, refer to the official ["how it works" language guide](/docs/how-it-works/languages) and the
32: [toolchain concept](/docs/concepts/toolchain) documentation!
33: 
34: info
35: 
36: The toolchain is optional but helps to solve an array of issues that developers face in their
37: day-to-day.
38: 
39: ## Enabling a toolchain
40: 
41: By default all tasks run through the
42: [system toolchain](/docs/how-it-works/languages#system-language-and-toolchain) and inherit no special
43: functionality. If you want to take advantage of this functionality, like dependency hashing, package
44: shorthand execution, and lockfile management, you'll need to enable the toolchain in
45: [`.moon/toolchains.yml`](/docs/config/toolchain). Otherwise, you can skip to the
46: [create a task](/docs/create-task) guide.
47: 
48: Begin by declaring the necessary configuration block, even if an empty object! This configuration
49: can also be injected using the [`moon toolchain add `](/docs/commands/toolchain/add) command
50: (doesn't support all languages).
51: 
52: .moon/toolchains.yml
53: 
54: ```
55: javascript:  packageManager: 'yarn'node: {}yarn: {}
56: ```
57: 
58: Although we've enabled the toolchain, language binaries must exist on `PATH` for task execution to
59: function correctly. Continue reading to learn how to automate this flow using tier 3 support.
60: 
61: ## Automatically installing a tool
62: 
63: One of the best features of moon is its integrated toolchain and automatic download and installation
64: of programming languages (when supported), for all developers and machines that moon runs on. This
65: feature solves the following pain points:
66: 
67: - Developers running tasks using different versions of languages.
68: 
69: - Version drift of languages between machines.
70: 
71: - Languages being installed through different version managers or install scripts.
72: 
73: - Language binaries not existing on `PATH`.
74: 
75: - How shell profiles should be configured.
76: 
77: If you have dealt with any of these pain points before and would like to eliminate them for you and
78: all your developers, you can try enabling moon's tier 3 support for supported tools. This is easily
79: done by defining the `version` field for each toolchain.
80: 
81: .moon/toolchains.yml
82: 
83: ```
84: javascript:  packageManager: 'yarn'node:  version: '20.0.0'yarn:  version: '4.0.0'
85: ```
86: 
87: When the `version` field is configured, moon will download and install the tool when a related task
88: is executed for the first time! It will also set the correct `PATH` lookups and environment
89: variables automatically. Amazing right?
90: 
91: ## Next steps
92: 
93: [Create a task](/docs/create-task)[Configure `.moon/toolchains.yml` further](/docs/config/toolchain)[Learn about the toolchain](/docs/concepts/toolchain)
94: 
95: ----
96: ## Notes / Comments / Lessons
97: 
98: - Collection method: sitemap discovery + markdown conversion.
99: - Conversion path: direct HTML fallback parser.
100: - This file is one page-level external snapshot in markdown `.ext.md` format.
101: ----
102:
