To enable a specific server from your organization’s remote config, add it to your local config with `enabled: true`: opencode.json ``` { "$schema": "https://opencode.ai/config.json", "mcp": { "jira": { "type": "remote", "url": "https://jira.example.com/mcp", "enabled": true } }} ``` Your local config values override the remote defaults. See [config precedence](/docs/config#precedence-order) for more details. ## [Local](#local) Add local MCP servers using `type` to `"local"` within the MCP object. opencode.jsonc ``` { "$schema": "https://opencode.ai/config.json", "mcp": { "my-local-mcp-server": { "type": "local", // Or ["bun", "x", "my-mcp-command"] "command": ["npx", "-y", "my-mcp-command"], "enabled": true, "environment": { "MY_ENV_VAR": "my_env_var_value", }, }, },} ``` The command is how the local MCP server is started. You can also pass in a list of environment variables as well. For example, here’s how you can add the test [`@modelcontextprotocol/server-everything`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@modelcontextprotocol/server-everything) MCP server. opencode.jsonc ``` { "$schema": "https://opencode.ai/config.json", "mcp": { "mcp_everything": { "type": "local", "command": ["npx", "-y", "@modelcontextprotocol/server-everything"], }, },} ``` And to use it I can add `use the mcp_everything tool` to my prompts. ``` use the mcp_everything tool to add the number 3 and 4 ``` #### [Options](#options) Her...

<path>/Users/alex/repos/vfp/dark-factory/docs/readmes/protobuf-schema-research.md</path>
<type>file</type>
<content>1: # Protobuf Schema Research Notes
2: 
3: Last reviewed: 2026-02-15
4: 
5: ## Scope
6: 
7: - Capture practical notes for authoring new `.proto` schemas.
8: - Support both `proto2` and `proto3` workflows.
9: - Document `protoc` usage for Rust and TypeScript generation paths.
10: 
11: ## Primary web sources
12: 
13: - OpenCode skills docs: https://opencode.ai/docs/skills/
14: - Protoc install docs: https://protobuf.dev/installation/
15: - Proto2 guide: https://protobuf.dev/programming-guides/proto2/
16: - Proto3 guide: https://protobuf.dev/programming-guides/proto3/
17: - Field presence note: https://protobuf.dev/programming-guides/field_presence/
18: - Rust generated code guide: https://protobuf.dev/reference/rust/rust-generated/
19: - Rust build reference: https://protobuf.dev/reference/rust/building-rust-protos/
20: - `prost-build` docs: https://docs.rs/prost-build/latest/prost_build/
21: - `tonic-prost-build` docs: https://docs.rs/tonic-prost-build/latest/tonic_prost_build/
22: - `ts-proto` README: https://github.com/stephenh/ts-proto
23: - `protobuf-ts` README: https://github.com/timostamm/protobuf-ts
24: 
25: ## Proto2 vs proto3 (what matters most)
26: 
27: - **Syntax line**
28:   - `proto2`: `syntax = "proto2";`
29:   - `proto3`: `syntax = "proto3";`
30: - **Cardinality labels**
31:   - `proto2`: `optional`, `required` (strongly discouraged), `repeated`, `map`.
32:   - `proto3`: `optional` (recommended), implicit singular (legacy style), `repeated`, `map`.
33: - **Required fields**
34:   - `proto2` only, but strongly discouraged for new schemas.
35:   - Not available in `proto3`.
36: - **Scalar default overrides**
37:   - `proto2`: supports `[default = ...]` on singular non-message fields.
38:   - `proto3`: no custom scalar defaults; language defaults apply.
39: - **Field presence**
40:   - `proto2`: explicit presence for singular fields.
41:   - `proto3`: explicit presence only with `optional` (or oneof/message); otherwise implicit for basic scalars.
42:   - Proto docs recommend using `optional` in proto3 for smoother compatibility.
43: - **Enum zero value**
44:   - `proto3`: first enum value must be `0`.
45:   - `proto2`: first value is default; using `_UNSPECIFIED = 0` is still safest.
46: - **Extensions and groups**
47:   - `proto2`: supports extensions; groups exist but are deprecated.
48:   - `proto3`: no general extension fields/groups in the same way.
49: - **Repeated scalar packing**
50:   - `proto2`: use `[packed = true]` for new repeated numeric fields.
51:   - `proto3`: repeated scalar numerics are packed by default.
52: - **Unknown fields**
53:   - Preserved in both proto2 and proto3 (binary format).
54: - **Interop note**
55:   - Proto2 and proto3 messages can interoperate across imports, but proto2 enums cannot be used directly in proto3 syntax.
56: 
57: ## Complete valid type list
58: 
59: ### Scalar field types (all proto syntaxes)
60: 
61: - `double`
62: - `float`
63: - `int32`
64: - `int64`
65: - `uint32`
66: - `uint64`
67: - `sint32`
68: - `sint64`
69: - `fixed32`
70: - `fixed64`
71: - `sfixed32`
72: - `sfixed64`
73: - `bool`
74: - `string`
75: - `bytes`
76: 
77: ### Non-scalar field type forms
78: 
79: - Message type (local or imported), for example `my.pkg.User`.
80: - Enum type (local or imported), for example `Status`.
81: - `map<K, V>` field form.
82:   - Valid map key types: `int32`, `int64`, `uint32`, `uint64`, `sint32`, `sint64`, `fixed32`, `fixed64`, `sfixed32`, `sfixed64`, `bool`, `string`.
83:   - Map values can be scalar, enum, or message types.
84: - `oneof` members (each member is a normal singular field declaration).
85: 
86: ### Well-known imported message types (common in schemas)
87: 
88: - `google.protobuf.Any`
89: - `google.protobuf.Timestamp`
90: - `google.protobuf.Duration`
91: - `google.protobuf.Empty`
92: - `google.protobuf.FieldMask`
93: - `google.protobuf.Struct`
94: - Wrapper messages in `google/protobuf/wrappers.proto`
95: 
96: ## Complete schema definition layout (reference)
97: 
98: The grammar allows flexible ordering in many places, but this layout is the safest boilerplate for new files.
99: 
100: ### Top-level statements
101: 
102: - `syntax = "proto2";` or `syntax = "proto3";` (first non-comment line)
103: - `package ...;` (optional, recommended)
104: - `import "...";`, `import public "...";`, or `import weak "...";`
105: - `option ... = ...;`
106: - `message ... { ... }`
107: - `enum ... { ... }`
108: - `service ... { ... }`
109: - `extend ... { ... }` (proto2 and custom-option patterns)
110: 
111: ### Message body statements
112: 
113: - Field declarations (`optional`/`required`/`repeated` in proto2, `optional`/implicit/repeated in proto3)
114: - `oneof ... { ... }`
115: - `map<key, value> ... = N;`
116: - Nested `message` and nested `enum`
117: - `reserved ...;` (numbers and/or names)
118: - `option ... = ...;`
119: - `extensions ...;` (proto2)
120: - `group` (proto2 legacy, deprecated)
121: - `extend ... { ... }`
122: 
123: ### Enum body statements
124: 
125: - Enum values: `NAME = N;`
126: - `option allow_alias = true;` and other enum options
127: - `reserved ...;` (numbers and/or names)
128: 
129: ### Service body statements
130: 
131: - Unary RPC:
132: 
133: ```proto
134: rpc GetThing(GetThingRequest) returns (GetThingResponse);
135: ```
136: 
137: - Streaming RPC:
138: 
139: ```proto
140: rpc Chat(stream ChatMessage) returns (stream ChatMessage);
141: ```
142: 
143: - RPC with method options block:
144: 
145: ```proto
146: rpc GetThing(GetThingRequest) returns (GetThingResponse) {
147:   option deprecated = true;
148: }
149: ```
150: 
151: ## Boilerplate templates
152: 
153: ### Proto3 boilerplate
154: 
155: ```proto
156: syntax = "proto3";
157: 
158: package example.v1;
159: 
160: import "google/protobuf/timestamp.proto";
161: 
162: option java_multiple_files = true;
163: 
164: message User {
165:   // Use optional for explicit scalar presence in proto3.
166:   optional string display_name = 1;
167:   string email = 2;
168:   google.protobuf.Timestamp created_at = 3;
169: 
170:   oneof contact_method {
171:     string phone = 4;
172:     string slack = 5;
173:   }
174: 
175:   map<string, string> labels = 6;
176: 
177:   reserved 7, 8;
178:   reserved "legacy_id";
179: }
180: 
181: enum UserState {
182:   USER_STATE_UNSPECIFIED = 0;
183:   USER_STATE_ACTIVE = 1;
184:   USER_STATE_DISABLED = 2;
185: }
186: 
187: service UserService {
188:   rpc GetUser(GetUserRequest) returns (GetUserResponse);
189: }
190: 
191: message GetUserRequest {
192:   string user_id = 1;
193: }
194: 
195: message GetUserResponse {
196:   User user = 1;
197: }
198: ```
199: 
200: ### Proto2 boilerplate
201: 
202: ```proto
203: syntax = "proto2";
204: 
205: package example.v1;
206: 
207: message User {
208:   optional string display_name = 1 [default = "unknown"];
209:   optional string email = 2;
210:   repeated string tags = 3;
211: 
212:   // Required is proto2-only and discouraged for new design.
213:   // required string id = 4;
214: 
215:   extensions 100 to max;
216: 
217:   reserved 5;
218:   reserved "legacy_id";
219: }
220: 
221: enum UserState {
222:   USER_STATE_UNSPECIFIED = 0;
223:   USER_STATE_ACTIVE = 1;
224: }
225: 
226: extend User {
227:   optional string external_profile = 100;
228: }
229: ```
230: 
231: ## Numbering and wire constraints quick reference
232: 
233: - Field numbers must be in `1..536870911`.
234: - Field numbers `19000..19999` are reserved by protobuf implementation.
235: - Never renumber existing fields.
236: - Never reuse removed field numbers or names.
237: 
238: ## Safe schema evolution checklist
239: 
240: - Never renumber existing fields.
241: - Never reuse deleted field numbers.
242: - Reserve removed field numbers and names using `reserved`.
243: - Prefer additive changes: add new fields, do not mutate existing wire meaning.
244: - Avoid `required` for new work.
245: - Use `oneof` when exactly one field must be present.
246: 
247: ## Protoc usage basics
248: 
249: - Verify installation:
250: 
251: ```bash
252: protoc --version
253: ```
254: 
255: - General compile shape:
256: 
257: ```bash
258: protoc -I proto --<LANG>_out=gen/<lang> proto/path/to/file.proto
259: ```
260: 
261: - Validate schema and emit descriptor set (useful for CI checks):
262: 
263: ```bash
264: protoc -I proto --include_imports --descriptor_set_out=gen/schema.pb proto/path/to/file.proto
265: ```
266: 
267: ## Rust generation patterns
268: 
269: Rust codegen is commonly done in `build.rs` wrappers that call `protoc` for you.
270: 
271: - `prost-build` example (`build.rs`):
272: 
273: ```rust
274: fn main() -> std::io::Result<()> {
275:     prost_build::compile_protos(&["proto/service.proto"], &["proto"])?;
276:     Ok(())
277: }
278: ```
279: 
280: - `tonic-prost-build` example (`build.rs`):
281: 
282: ```rust
283: fn main() {
284:     tonic_prost_build::configure()
285:         .compile_protos(&["proto/service.proto"], &["proto"])
286:         .unwrap();
287: }
288: ```
289: 
290: - `protobuf` crate ecosystem example (`build.rs`, from protobuf-example):
291: 
292: ```rust
293: use protobuf_codegen::CodeGen;
294: 
295: fn main() {
296:     CodeGen::new()
297:         .inputs(["proto_example/foo.proto", "proto_example/bar/bar.proto"])
298:         .include("proto")
299:         .dependency(protobuf_well_known_types::get_dependency("protobuf_well_known_types"))
300:         .generate_and_compile()
301:         .unwrap();
302: }
303: ```
304: 
305: ## TypeScript generation patterns
306: 
307: TypeScript typically uses `protoc` plugins.
308: 
309: - `ts-proto` quickstart:
310: 
311: ```bash
312: protoc \
313:   --plugin=./node_modules/.bin/protoc-gen-ts_proto \
314:   --ts_proto_out=gen/ts \
315:   --ts_proto_opt=esModuleInterop=true \
316:   -I proto \
317:   proto/path/to/file.proto
318: ```
319: 
320: - `@protobuf-ts/plugin` quickstart:
321: 
322: ```bash
323: npx protoc --ts_out gen/ts --proto_path proto proto/path/to/file.proto
324: ```
325: 
326: ## Agent defaults for new schema requests
327: 
328: - Ask which syntax to use: `proto2` or `proto3`.
329: - If unspecified, recommend `proto3` with explicit `optional` for scalar presence.
330: - Ask which TypeScript generator to target: `ts-proto` or `@protobuf-ts/plugin`.
331: - If unspecified, recommend `ts-proto` for idiomatic TS interfaces and flexible options.
332: - Always call out features that are syntax-specific (for example `required`/extensions/default overrides in proto2).
333: 

(End of file - total 333 lines)

<content>1: ---
2: name: external-docs-scraping
3: description: Create and run Bun scraper scripts that snapshot external docs into split `.ext.md` files under `docs/external/<source>/`.
4: ---
5: 
6: ## What I do
7: 
8: - Standardize how we add a new external docs snapshot source.
9: - Create or adapt a Bun script in `scripts/` using existing scraper conventions.
10: - Produce split per-page `*.ext.md` files plus an `index.ext.md` under `docs/external/<source>/`.
11: - This skill remains compatible, but prefer `.opencode/skills/docs-scraping/SKILL.md` for generic user-request driven scraping workflows.
12: 
13: ## When to use me
14: 
15: Use this when the task is to add a new external docs source like the existing moonrepo snapshot flow.
16: 
17: ## Output contract
18: 
19: - Script file: `scripts/scrape_<source>_docs.sh.ts`
20: - Output directory: `docs/external/<source>/`
21: - Output files:
22:   - One page-level `*.ext.md` file per source docs page
23:   - `index.ext.md` linking all generated page files
24: 
25: ## Script conventions
26: 
27: - Use Bun shebang script format: `#!/usr/bin/env bun`.
28: - Reuse shared helpers from `scripts/helpers/` (for example `findRepoRoot`).
29: - Keep script deterministic and idempotent where practical.
30: - Default to sitemap or deterministic page discovery over fragile crawling.
31: - Clear prior `*.ext.md` files in the target output directory before regenerating.
32: 
33: ## Page/index format conventions
34: 
35: - Keep each page file in `.ext.md` format with:
36:   - metadata block (captured timestamp, source URL/path, keywords, summary)
37:   - normalized markdown body
38:   - notes section describing capture/conversion method
39: - Keep `index.ext.md` as a full page inventory with status summary (`ok`/`failed`).
40: 
41: ## Implementation workflow
42: 
43: 1. Identify docs root and discovery method (`sitemap.xml` preferred).
44: 2. Create script in `scripts/` following `scrape_moon_docs.sh.ts` structure.
45: 3. Map URLs to stable flattened filenames (for example `docs__guides__intro.ext.md`).
46: 4. Scrape each page with a resilient strategy:
47:    - Primary: `r.jina.ai` markdown proxy
48:    - Fallback: direct HTML fetch and conversion
49: 5. Write all page snapshots and `index.ext.md` to `docs/external/<source>/`.
50: 6. Run the script once and report page count + success/failure totals.
51: 7. Update `README.md` and `AGENTS.md` when a new scraper entrypoint is added.
52: 
53: ## Notes
54: 
55: - Prefer explicit logs using project format: `Docs // Scrape // Message (...)`.
56: - Do not include secrets, auth tokens, or private pages in snapshots.
57: - If scraping is partially blocked, still produce index entries marking failed pages.
58: 

(End of file - total 58 lines)
</content>

name: external-docs-scraping
description: Create and run Bun scraper scripts that snapshot external docs into split `.ext.md` files under `docs/external/<source>/`.
---

## What I do

- Standardize how we add a new external docs snapshot source.
- Create or adapt a Bun script in `scripts/` using existing scraper conventions.
- Produce split per-page `*.ext.md` files plus an `index.ext.md` under `docs/external/<source>/`.
- This skill remains compatible, but prefer `.opencode/skills/docs-scraping/SKILL.md` for generic user-request driven scraping workflows.

## When to use me

Use this when the task is to add a new external docs source like the existing moonrepo snapshot flow.

## Output contract

- Script file: `scripts/scrape_<source>_docs.sh.ts`
- Output directory: `docs/external/<source>/`

state.output:
<path>/Users/alex/repos/vfp/dark-factory/scripts/scrape_moon_docs.sh.ts</path>
<type>file</type>
<content>1: #!/usr/bin/env bun
2: 
3: import { existsSync, mkdirSync, readdirSync, rmSync } from "node:fs";
4: import { dirname, resolve } from "node:path";
5: import { findRepoRoot } from "./helpers/run_root.sh.ts";
6: 
7: type ScrapeMode = "jina" | "html";
8: 
9: type ScrapeResult = {
10:   url: string;
11:   ok: boolean;
12:   markdown?: string;
13:   error?: string;
14:   mode?: ScrapeMode;
15: };
16: 
17: type PageArtifact = ScrapeResult & {
18:   fileName: string;
19:   sourcePath: string;
20: };
21: 
22: const SITEMAP_URL = "https://moonrepo.dev/sitemap.xml";
23: const DOCS_ROOT = "https://moonrepo.dev/docs";
24: const DEFAULT_OUTPUT_DIR_RELATIVE = "docs/external/moonrepo";
25: const CONCURRENCY = 4;
26: const SUMMARY_MAX_CHARS = 240;
27: 
28: function decodeEntities(value: string): string {
29:   return value
30:     .replaceAll("&", "&")
31:     .replaceAll(""", '"')
32:     .replaceAll("'", "'")
33:     .replaceAll("'", "'")
34:     .replaceAll("'", "'")
35:     .replaceAll(" ", " ")
36:     .replaceAll("<", "<")
37:     .replaceAll(">", ">");
38: }
39: 
40: function stripJinaEnvelope(markdown: string): string {
41:   return markdown
42:     .replace(/^Title:.*?\nURL Source:.*?\nMarkdown Content:\n/s, "")
43:     .trim();
44: }
45: 
46: function stripTags(value: string): string {
47:   return value.replace(/<[^>]+>/g, "");
48: }
49: 
50: function plainTextFromHtml(value: string): string {
51:   return decodeEntities(stripTags(value).replace(/\s+/g, " ")).trim();
52: }
53: 
54: function extractMainHtml(html: string): string {
55:   const markdownBlockMatch = html.match(
56:     /<div class="theme-doc-markdown markdown">([\s\S]*?)<footer class="theme-doc-footer/s,
57:   );
58: 
59:   if (markdownBlockMatch?.[1]) {
60:     return markdownBlockMatch[1];
61:   }
62: 
63:   const articleMatch = html.match(/<article>([\s\S]*?)<\/article>/s);
64:   if (articleMatch?.[1]) {
65:     return articleMatch[1];
66:   }
67: 
68:   const mainMatch = html.match(/<main[^>]*>([\s\S]*?)<\/main>/s);
69:   return mainMatch?.[1] ?? html;
70: }
71: 
72: function htmlToMarkdown(html: string): string {
73:   let content = extractMainHtml(html);
74: 
75:   content = content
76:     .replace(/<script[\s\S]*?<\/script>/gi, "")
77:     .replace(/<style[\s\S]*?<\/style>/gi, "")
78:     .replace(/<a[^>]*class="hash-link"[^>]*>[\s\S]*?<\/a>/gi, "")
79:     .replace(/<span[^>]*aria-hidden="true"[^>]*>[\s\S]*?<\/span>/gi, "");
80: 
81:   content = content.replace(
82:     /<pre[^>]*><code[^>]*>([\s\S]*?)<\/code><\/pre>/gi,
83:     (_match, code) => {
84:       const normalizedCode = decodeEntities(
85:         stripTags(code)
86:           .replace(/<br\s*\/?>/gi, "\n")
87:           .replace(/\n{3,}/g, "\n\n")
88:           .trim(),
89:       );
90: 
91:       if (!normalizedCode) {
92:         return "";
93:       }
94: 
95:       return `\n\n\`\`\`\n${normalizedCode}\n\`\`\`\n\n`;
96:     },
97:   );
98: 
99:   content = content.replace(/<code[^>]*>([\s\S]*?)<\/code>/gi, (_match, code) => {
100:     const normalizedCode = decodeEntities(stripTags(code)).trim();
101:     return normalizedCode ? `\`${normalizedCode}\`` : "";
102:   });
103: 
104:   content = content.replace(
105:     /<a[^>]*href="([^"]+)"[^>]*>([\s\S]*?)<\/a>/gi,
106:     (_match, href, label) => {
107:       const text = plainTextFromHtml(label);
108:       if (!text) {
109:         return "";
110:       }
111: 
112:       return `[${text}](${decodeEntities(href)})`;
113:     },
114:   );
115: 
116:   content = content.replace(/<h([1-6])[^>]*>([\s\S]*?)<\/h\1>/gi, (_match, level, inner) => {
117:     const heading = plainTextFromHtml(inner);
118:     if (!heading) {
119:       return "";
120:     }
121: 
122:     return `\n\n${"#".repeat(Number(level))} ${heading}\n\n`;
123:   });
124: 
125:   content = content.replace(/<li[^>]*>([\s\S]*?)<\/li>/gi, (_match, inner) => {
126:     const line = plainTextFromHtml(inner);
127:     return line ? `- ${line}\n` : "";
128:   });
129: 
130:   content = content
131:     .replace(/<br\s*\/?>/gi, "\n")
132:     .replace(/<\/(p|div|section|article|header|ul|ol|table|tr)>/gi, "\n\n")
133:     .replace(/<(p|div|section|article|header|ul|ol|table|tr)[^>]*>/gi, "\n")
134:     .replace(/<t[hd][^>]*>([\s\S]*?)<\/t[hd]>/gi, (_match, inner) => {
135:       const cell = plainTextFromHtml(inner);
136:       return cell ? `${cell} ` : "";
137:     });
138: 
139:   content = decodeEntities(content)
140:     .replace(/<[^>]+>/g, "")
141:     .replace(/[ \t]+\n/g, "\n")
142:     .replace(/\n{3,}/g, "\n\n")
143:     .trim();
144: 
145:   return content;
146: }
147: 
148: function extractDocsUrls(sitemapXml: string): string[] {
149:   const urls = Array.from(sitemapXml.matchAll(/<loc>(.*?)<\/loc>/g), (match) =>
150:     decodeEntities(match[1]?.trim() ?? ""),
151:   )
152:     .filter((url) => url.startsWith(DOCS_ROOT))
153:     .filter((url) => !url.includes("/docs/tags"))
154:     .filter((url) => !url.includes("#"));
155: 
156:   return Array.from(new Set(urls)).sort((a, b) => a.localeCompare(b));
157: }
158: 
159: function sanitizeSegment(value: string): string {
160:   const clean = decodeURIComponent(value)
161:     .toLowerCase()
162:     .replace(/[^a-z0-9]+/g, "-")
163:     .replace(/^-+|-+$/g, "");
164: 
165:   return clean || "page";
166: }
167: 
168: function sourcePathFromUrl(url: string): string {
169:   const pathname = new URL(url).pathname.replace(/\/+$/, "") || "/docs";
170:   return pathname;
171: }
172: 
173: function fileStemFromUrl(url: string): string {
174:   const sourcePath = sourcePathFromUrl(url);
175: 
176:   if (sourcePath === "/docs") {
177:     return "docs";
178:   }
179: 
180:   const relative = sourcePath.replace(/^\/docs\/?/, "");
181:   const segments = relative
182:     .split("/")
183:     .filter(Boolean)
184:     .map(sanitizeSegment);
185: 
186:   if (segments.length === 0) {
187:     return "docs";
188:   }
189: 
190:   return ["docs", ...segments].join("__");
191: }
192: 
193: function extractSummary(markdown: string): string {
194:   const lines = markdown.split("\n");
195:   let inCodeBlock = false;
196: 
197:   for (const rawLine of lines) {
198:     const line = rawLine.trim();
199: 
200:     if (line.startsWith("```") || line.startsWith("~~~")) {
201:       inCodeBlock = !inCodeBlock;
202:       continue;
203:     }
204: 
205:     if (inCodeBlock) {
206:       continue;
207:     }
208: 
209:     if (!line || line.startsWith("#") || line.startsWith("- [") || line.startsWith("```")) {
210:       continue;
211:     }
212: 
213:     if (line.length <= 25) {
214:       continue;
215:     }
216: 
217:     if (line.length > SUMMARY_MAX_CHARS) {
218:       return `${line.slice(0, SUMMARY_MAX_CHARS - 3)}...`;
219:     }
220: 
221:     return line;
222:   }
223: 
224:   return "moonrepo documentation page snapshot.";
225: }
226: 
227: function keywordsForPath(sourcePath: string): string {
228:   const dynamic = sourcePath
229:     .split("/")
230:     .filter(Boolean)
231:     .slice(1)
232:     .map((part) => part.replace(/[^a-zA-Z0-9]+/g, " "))
233:     .filter(Boolean)
234:     .join(", ");
235: 
236:   const base = "moon, moonrepo, docs, monorepo, build";
237:   return dynamic ? `${base}, ${dynamic}` : base;
238: }
239: 
240: function buildPageMarkdown(result: PageArtifact, capturedAt: string): string {
241:   const pageSummary = result.ok
242:     ? extractSummary(result.markdown ?? "")
243:     : `Scrape failed: ${result.error ?? "unknown error"}`;
244: 
245:   const pageBody = result.ok
246:     ? result.markdown?.trim() ?? ""
247:     : `> Scrape failed: ${result.error ?? "unknown error"}`;
248: 
249:   return [
250:     "----",
251:     "## External Docs Snapshot // moonrepo",
252:     "",
253:     `- Captured: ${capturedAt}`,
254:     `- Source root: ${DOCS_ROOT}`,
255:     `- Source page: ${result.sourcePath}`,
256:     `- Keywords: ${keywordsForPath(result.sourcePath)}`,
257:     `- Summary: ${pageSummary}`,
258:     "----",
259:     "",
260:     `Source: ${result.url}`,
261:     "",
262:     pageBody,
263:     "",
264:     "----",
265:     "## Notes / Comments / Lessons",
266:     "",
267:     "- Collection method: sitemap discovery + markdown conversion.",
268:     `- Conversion path: ${result.mode === "html" ? "direct HTML fallback parser" : "r.jina.ai markdown proxy"}.`,
269:     "- This file is one page-level external snapshot in markdown `.ext.md` format.",
270:     "----",
271:     "",
272:   ].join("\n");
273: }
274: 
275: function buildIndexMarkdown(
276:   artifacts: PageArtifact[],
277:   capturedAt: string,
278:   outputDirRelative: string,
279: ): string {
280:   const successCount = artifacts.filter((artifact) => artifact.ok).length;
281:   const failureCount = artifacts.length - successCount;
282: 
283:   const pageList = artifacts
284:     .map((artifact) => {
285:       const status = artifact.ok ? "ok" : "failed";
286:       const mode = artifact.mode ?? "unknown";
287:       return `- [${artifact.fileName}](./${artifact.fileName}) - ${artifact.sourcePath} (${status},mode=${mode})`;
288:     })
289:     .join("\n");
290: 
291:   return [
292:     "----",
293:     "## External Docs Index // moonrepo",
294:     "",
295:     `- Captured: ${capturedAt}`,
296:     `- Source root: ${DOCS_ROOT}`,
297:     `- Output directory: ${outputDirRelative}`,
298:     `- Scope: ${artifacts.length} pages under /docs (excluding /docs/tags)`,
299:     "- Keywords: moon, moonrepo, docs index, monorepo, build system, toolchain, proto",
300:     "- Summary: This index links one `.ext.md` file per docs page snapshot for moonrepo.",
301:     "----",
302:     "",
303:     "## Pages",
304:     "",
305:     pageList,
306:     "",
307:     "----",
308:     "## Notes / Comments / Lessons",
309:     "",
310:     "- Per-page files are flattened in this directory and prefixed with `docs` in the filename stem.",
311:     "- Regenerate by re-running the scraper script; old `.ext.md` files in this directory are replaced.",
312:     `- Capture results: success=${successCount}, failed=${failureCount}.`,
313:     "----",
314:     "",
315:   ].join("\n");
316: }
317: 
318: async function fetchText(url: string): Promise<string> {
319:   const response = await fetch(url, {
320:     headers: {
321:       "user-agent": "dark-factory-doc-scraper/1.0",
322:     },
323:   });
324: 
325:   if (!response.ok) {
326:     throw new Error(`Request failed (${response.status}) for ${url}`);
327:   }
328: 
329:   return await response.text();
330: }
331: 
332: async function mapConcurrent<T, R>(
333:   values: T[],
334:   limit: number,
335:   map: (value: T, index: number) => Promise<R>,
336: ): Promise<R[]> {
337:   const results = new Array<R>(values.length);
338:   let index = 0;
339: 
340:   async function worker(): Promise<void> {
341:     while (true) {
342:       const currentIndex = index;
343:       index += 1;
344: 
345:       if (currentIndex >= values.length) {
346:         return;
347:       }
348: 
349:       results[currentIndex] = await map(values[currentIndex], currentIndex);
350:     }
351:   }
352: 
353:   const workerCount = Math.min(limit, values.length);
354:   await Promise.all(Array.from({ length: workerCount }, () => worker()));
355:   return results;
356: }
357: 
358: async function scrapeDocsPage(url: string, count: number, total: number): Promise<ScrapeResult> {
359:   const jinaUrl = `https://r.jina.ai/http://${url.replace(/^https?:\/\//, "")}`;
360: 
361:   try {
362:     console.log(`Docs // Scrape // ${count}/${total} ${url}`);
363: 
364:     try {
365:       const markdown = stripJinaEnvelope(await fetchText(jinaUrl));
366:       if (markdown) {
367:         return {
368:           url,
369:           ok: true,
370:           markdown,
371:           mode: "jina",
372:         };
373:       }
374:     } catch {
375:       // Fall through to direct HTML scrape.
376:     }
377: 
378:     const html = await fetchText(url);
379:     const markdown = htmlToMarkdown(html);
380: 
381:     if (!markdown) {
382:       return {
383:         url,
384:         ok: false,
385:         error: "No markdown content returned from HTML fallback",
386:       };
387:     }
388: 
389:     return {
390:       url,
391:       ok: true,
392:       markdown,
393:       mode: "html",
394:     };
395:   } catch (error) {
396:     return {
397:       url,
398:       ok: false,
399:       error: error instanceof Error ? error.message : "Unknown scrape error",
400:     };
401:   }
402: }
403: 
404: function resolveOutputDirectory(repoRoot: string, outputArg?: string): string {
405:   if (!outputArg) {
406:     return resolve(repoRoot, DEFAULT_OUTPUT_DIR_RELATIVE);
407:   }
408: 
409:   const resolved = resolve(repoRoot, outputArg);
410:   if (resolved.endsWith(".md")) {
411:     return dirname(resolved);
412:   }
413: 
414:   return resolved;
415: }
416: 
417: function clearExistingExtFiles(outputDir: string): void {
418:   if (!existsSync(outputDir)) {
419:     return;
420:   }
421: 
422:   for (const entry of readdirSync(outputDir, { withFileTypes: true })) {
423:     if (!entry.isFile()) {
424:       continue;
425:     }
426: 
427:     if (!entry.name.endsWith(".ext.md")) {
428:       continue;
429:     }
430: 
431:     rmSync(resolve(outputDir, entry.name));
432:   }
433: }
434: 
435: const repoRoot = findRepoRoot(import.meta.dir);
436: const outputArg = Bun.argv[2];
437: const outputDir = resolveOutputDirectory(repoRoot, outputArg);
438: const outputDirRelative = outputDir.startsWith(repoRoot)
439:   ? outputDir.slice(repoRoot.length + 1)
440:   : outputDir;
441: 
442: mkdirSync(outputDir, { recursive: true });
443: clearExistingExtFiles(outputDir);
444: 
445: const sitemapXml = await fetchText(SITEMAP_URL);
446: const docsUrls = extractDocsUrls(sitemapXml);
447: 
448: if (docsUrls.length === 0) {
449:   throw new Error("No docs URLs found in moonrepo sitemap");
450: }
451: 
452: const scrapeResults = await mapConcurrent(docsUrls, CONCURRENCY, (url, index) =>
453:   scrapeDocsPage(url, index + 1, docsUrls.length),
454: );
455: 
456: const usedNames = new Map<string, number>();
457: const artifacts: PageArtifact[] = scrapeResults.map((result) => {
458:   const stem = fileStemFromUrl(result.url);
459:   const seen = usedNames.get(stem) ?? 0;
460:   usedNames.set(stem, seen + 1);
461: 
462:   const suffix = seen === 0 ? "" : `__${seen + 1}`;
463:   const fileName = `${stem}${suffix}.ext.md`;
464: 
465:   return {
466:     ...result,
467:     fileName,
468:     sourcePath: sourcePathFromUrl(result.url),
469:   };
470: });
471: 
472: const capturedAt = new Date().toISOString();
473: 
474: for (const artifact of artifacts) {
475:   const pagePath = resolve(outputDir, artifact.fileName);
476:   const pageContent = buildPageMarkdown(artifact, capturedAt);
477:   await Bun.write(pagePath, pageContent);
478: }
479: 
480: const indexContent = buildIndexMarkdown(artifacts, capturedAt, outputDirRelative);
481: await Bun.write(resolve(outputDir, "index.ext.md"), indexContent);
482: 
483: const successCount = artifacts.filter((artifact) => artifact.ok).length;
484: const failureCount = artifacts.length - successCount;
485: 
486: console.log(
487:   `Docs // Scrape // Wrote split external docs (pages=${artifacts.length},ok=${successCount},failed=${failureCount},dir=${outputDir})`,
488: );
489: 

(End of file - total 489 lines)
</content>

files.after:
$schema: "https://moonrepo.dev/schemas/project.json"

language: "typescript"
stack: "backend"
layer: "application"

tasks:
  install:
    command: "bun install"
    options:
      cache: false

  codegen-proto:
    command: "bun scripts/proto_codegen_core.sh.ts"
    deps:
      - "install"
    inputs:
      - "/schemas/**/*.proto"
      - "package.json"
      - "bun.lock"
    outputs:
      - "src/gen/proto/"
    options:
      cache: false
      runFromWorkspaceRoot: true

  start:
    command: "bun run start"
    deps:
      - "codegen-proto"
    options:
      cache: false

  dev:
    command: "bun run dev"
    deps:
      - "codegen-proto"
    options:
      cache: false
      persistent: true

diffs.after:
$schema: "https://moonrepo.dev/schemas/toolchain.json"

# Enable JavaScript ecosystem support and tell moon we use Bun packages.
javascript:
  packageManager: "bun"

# Turn on Bun toolchain integration for task execution.
# Version is currently managed by .prototools (bun = "latest").
bun: {}

diffs.before:
$schema: "https://moonrepo.dev/schemas/workspace.json"

projects:
  core: "core"

defaultProject: "core"

vcs:
  manager: "git"
  defaultBranch: "main"

pipeline:
  logRunningCommand: true
diffs.after:
$schema: "https://moonrepo.dev/schemas/workspace.json"

# Register workspace projects by ID -> relative path.
projects:
  core: "core"

# Allow `moon run <task>` to default to core when project is omitted.
defaultProject: "core"

# Keep VCS settings explicit for deterministic affected-file behavior.
vcs:
  manager: "git"
  defaultBranch: "main"

# Helpful while bootstrapping: show the fully resolved command moon executes.
pipeline:
  logRunningCommand: true

Documentation/Client APIs/C

Overview

> The latest stable version of the DuckDB C API is 1.4.4.

DuckDB implements a custom C API modeled somewhat following the SQLite C API. The API is contained in the 
```plaintext
duckdb.h
```
 header. Continue to [Startup & Shutdown](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/c/connect.html) to get started, or check out the [Full API overview](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/c/api.html).

We also provide a SQLite API wrapper which means that if your applications is programmed against the SQLite C API, you can re-link to DuckDB and it should continue working. See the [```plaintext sqlite_api_wrapper ```](https://github.com/duckdb/duckdb/tree/main/tools/sqlite3_api_wrapper) folder in our source repository for more information.

[Installation](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/c/overview.html#installation)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The DuckDB C API can be installed as part of the 
```plaintext
libduckdb
```
 packages. Please see the [installation page](http://duckdb.org/install/?environment=cplusplus) for details.

Documentation/Client APIs/CLI

Command Line Arguments

The table below summarizes DuckDB's command line options. To list all command line options, use the command:

```
duckdb -help
```

For a list of dot commands available in the CLI shell, see the [Dot Commands page](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html).

| Argument | Description |
| --- | --- |
| ```plaintext -append ``` | Append the database to the end of the file |
| ```plaintext -ascii ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to ```plaintext ascii ``` |
| ```plaintext -bail ``` | Stop after hitting an error |
| ```plaintext -batch ``` | Force batch I/O |
| ```plaintext -box ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to ```plaintext box ``` |
| ```plaintext -column ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to ```plaintext column ``` |
| ```plaintext -cmd COMMAND ``` | Run ```plaintext COMMAND ``` before reading ```plaintext stdin ``` |
| ```plaintext -c COMMAND ``` | Run ```plaintext COMMAND ``` and exit |
| ```plaintext -csv ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to ```plaintext csv ``` |
| ```plaintext -echo ``` | Print commands before execution |
| ```plaintext -f FILENAME ``` | Run the script in ```plaintext FILENAME ``` and exit. Note that the ```plaintext ~/.duckdbrc ``` is read and executed first (if it exists) |
| ```plaintext -init FILENAME ``` | Run the script in ```plaintext FILENAME ``` upon startup (instead of ```plaintext ~/.duckdbrc ``` ) |
| ```plaintext -header ``` | Turn headers on |
| ```plaintext -help ``` | Show this message |
| ```plaintext -html ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to HTML |
| ```plaintext -interactive ``` | Force interactive I/O |
| ```plaintext -json ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to ```plaintext json ``` |
| ```plaintext -line ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to ```plaintext line ``` |
| ```plaintext -list ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to ```plaintext list ``` |
| ```plaintext -markdown ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to ```plaintext markdown ``` |
| ```plaintext -newline SEP ``` | Set output row separator. Default: ```plaintext \n ``` |
| ```plaintext -nofollow ``` | Refuse to open symbolic links to database files |
| ```plaintext -noheader ``` | Turn headers off |
| ```plaintext -no-stdin ``` | Exit after processing options instead of reading stdin |
| ```plaintext -nullvalue TEXT ``` | Set text string for ```plaintext NULL ``` values. Default: ```plaintext NULL ``` |
| ```plaintext -quote ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to ```plaintext quote ``` |
| ```plaintext -readonly ``` | Open the database read-only. This option also supports attaching to remote databases via HTTPS |
| ```plaintext -s COMMAND ``` | Run ```plaintext COMMAND ``` and exit |
| ```plaintext -separator SEP ``` | Set output column separator to ```plaintext SEP ``` . Default: ```plaintext | ``` |
| ```plaintext -storage-version VER ``` | Database storage compatibility version to use. |
| ```plaintext -table ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) to ```plaintext table ``` |
| ```plaintext -ui ``` | Loads and starts the [DuckDB UI](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/core_extensions/ui.html). If the UI is not yet installed, it installs the ```plaintext ui ``` extension |
| ```plaintext -unsigned ``` | Allow loading of [unsigned extensions](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/extensions/overview.html#unsigned-extensions). This option is intended to be used for developing extensions. Consult the [Securing DuckDB page](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/operations_manual/securing_duckdb/securing_extensions.html) for guidelines on how set up DuckDB in a secure manner |
| ```plaintext -version ``` | Show DuckDB version |

[Passing a Sequence of Arguments](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/arguments.html#passing-a-sequence-of-arguments)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Note that the CLI arguments are processed in order, similarly to the behavior of the SQLite CLI. For example:

```
duckdb -csv -c 'SELECT 42 AS hello' -json -c 'SELECT 84 AS world'
```

Returns the following:

```
hello
42
[{"world":84}]
```

Documentation/Client APIs/CLI

Autocomplete

The shell offers context-aware autocomplete of SQL queries through the [```plaintext autocomplete ``` extension](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/core_extensions/autocomplete.html). autocomplete is triggered by pressing 
```plaintext
Tab
```
.

Multiple autocomplete suggestions can be present. You can cycle forwards through the suggestions by repeatedly pressing 
```plaintext
Tab
```
, or 
```plaintext
Shift+Tab
```
 to cycle backwards. autocompletion can be reverted by pressing 
```plaintext
ESC
```
 twice.

The shell autocompletes four different groups:

*   Keywords
*   Table names and table functions
*   Column names and scalar functions
*   File names

The shell looks at the position in the SQL statement to determine which of these autocompletions to trigger. For example:

```
SELECT s
```

```
student_id
```

```
SELECT student_id F
```

```
FROM
```

```
SELECT student_id FROM g
```

```
grades
```

```
SELECT student_id FROM 'd
```

```
'data/
```

```
SELECT student_id FROM 'data/
```

```
'data/grades.csv
```

Documentation/Client APIs/CLI

Dot Commands

Dot commands are available in the DuckDB CLI client. To use one of these commands, begin the line with a period (
```plaintext
.
```
) immediately followed by the name of the command you wish to execute. Additional arguments to the command are entered, space separated, after the command. If an argument must contain a space, either single or double quotes may be used to wrap that parameter. Dot commands must be entered on a single line, and no whitespace may occur before the period. No semicolon is required at the end of the line. To see available commands, use the 
```plaintext
.help
```
 command.

[List of Dot Commands](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#list-of-dot-commands)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

| Command | Description |
| --- | --- |
| ```sql .bail on/off ``` | Stop after hitting an error. Default: ```plaintext off ``` |
| ```sql .binary on/off ``` | Turn binary output ```plaintext on ``` or ```plaintext off ``` . Default: ```plaintext off ``` |
| ```sql .cd DIRECTORY ``` | Change the working directory to ```plaintext DIRECTORY ``` |
| ```sql .changes on/off ``` | Show number of rows changed by SQL |
| ```sql .columns ``` | Column-wise rendering of query results |
| ```sql .constant COLOR ``` | Sets the syntax highlighting color used for constant values |
| ```sql .constantcode CODE ``` | Sets the syntax highlighting terminal code used for constant values |
| ```sql .databases ``` | List names and files of attached databases |
| ```sql .echo on/off ``` | Turn command echo ```plaintext on ``` or ```plaintext off ``` |
| ```sql .exit CODE ``` | Exit this program with return-code ```plaintext CODE ``` |
| ```sql .headers on/off ``` | Turn display of headers ```plaintext on ``` or ```plaintext off ``` . Does not apply to duckbox mode |
| ```sql .help -all PATTERN ``` | Show help text for ```plaintext PATTERN ``` |
| ```sql .highlight on/off ``` | Toggle syntax highlighting in the shell ```plaintext on ``` / ```plaintext off ``` . See the [query syntax highlighting section](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#configuring-the-query-syntax-highlighter) for more details |
| ```sql .highlight_colors COMPONENT COLOR ``` | Configure the color of each component in (duckbox only). See the [result syntax highlighting section](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#configuring-the-query-syntax-highlighter) for more details |
| ```sql .highlight_results on/off ``` | Toggle highlighting in result tables ```plaintext on ``` / ```plaintext off ``` (duckbox only). See the [result syntax highlighting section](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#configuring-the-query-syntax-highlighter) for more details |
| ```sql .import FILE TABLE ``` | Import data from ```plaintext FILE ``` into ```plaintext TABLE ``` |
| ```sql .indexes TABLE ``` | Show names of indexes |
| ```sql .keyword COLOR ``` | Sets the syntax highlighting color used for keywords |
| ```sql .keywordcode CODE ``` | Sets the syntax highlighting terminal code used for keywords |
| ```sql .large_number_rendering all/footer/off ``` | Toggle readable rendering of large numbers (duckbox only, default: ```plaintext footer ``` ) |
| ```sql .log FILE/off ``` | Turn logging ```plaintext on ``` or ```plaintext off ``` . ```plaintext FILE ``` can be ```plaintext stderr ``` / ```plaintext stdout ``` |
| ```sql .maxrows COUNT ``` | Sets the maximum number of rows for display. Only for [duckbox mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) |
| ```sql .maxwidth COUNT ``` | Sets the maximum width in characters. 0 defaults to terminal width. Only for [duckbox mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) |
| ```sql .mode MODE TABLE ``` | Set [output mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html) |
| ```sql .multiline ``` | Set multi-line mode (default) |
| ```sql .nullvalue STRING ``` | Use ```plaintext STRING ``` in place of ```plaintext NULL ``` values. Default: ```plaintext NULL ``` |
| ```sql .once OPTIONS FILE ``` | Output for the next SQL command only to ```plaintext FILE ``` |
| ```sql .open OPTIONS FILE ``` | Close existing database and reopen ```plaintext FILE ``` |
| ```sql .output FILE ``` | Send output to ```plaintext FILE ``` or ```plaintext stdout ``` if ```plaintext FILE ``` is omitted |
| ```sql .print STRING... ``` | Print literal ```plaintext STRING ``` |
| ```sql .progress_bar COMPONENT ``` | Set the progress bar component styles |
| ```sql .prompt OPTIONS CONTINUE ``` | Replace the standard prompts |
| ```sql .quit ``` | Exit this program |
| ```sql .read FILE ``` | Read input from ```plaintext FILE ``` |
| ```sql .rows ``` | Row-wise rendering of query results (default) |
| ```sql .safe_mode ``` | Activates [safe mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/safe_mode.html) |
| ```sql .schema PATTERN ``` | Show the ```plaintext CREATE ``` statements matching ```plaintext PATTERN ``` |
| ```sql .separator COL ROW ``` | Change the column and row separators |
| ```sql .shell CMD ARGS... ``` | Run ```plaintext CMD ``` with ```plaintext ARGS... ``` in a system shell |
| ```sql .show ``` | Show the current values for various settings |
| ```sql .singleline ``` | Set single-line mode |
| ```sql .system CMD ARGS... ``` | Run ```plaintext CMD ``` with ```plaintext ARGS... ``` in a system shell |
| ```sql .tables TABLE ``` | List names of tables [matching ```plaintext LIKE ``` pattern](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/sql/functions/pattern_matching.html) ```plaintext TABLE ``` |
| ```sql .timer on/off ``` | Turn SQL timer ```plaintext on ``` or ```plaintext off ``` . SQL statements separated by ```plaintext ; ``` but _not_ separated via newline are measured together |
| ```sql .width NUM1 NUM2 ... ``` | Set minimum column widths for columnar output |

[Using the ```plaintext .help ``` Command](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#using-the-help-command)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The 
```plaintext
.help
```
 text may be filtered by passing in a text string as the first argument.

```
.help m
```

```
.maxrows COUNT           Sets the maximum number of rows for display (default: 40). Only for duckbox mode.
.maxwidth COUNT          Sets the maximum width in characters. 0 defaults to terminal width. Only for duckbox mode.
.mode MODE ?TABLE?       Set output mode
```

[```plaintext .output ``` : Writing Results to a File](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#output-writing-results-to-a-file)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By default, the DuckDB CLI sends results to the terminal's standard output. However, this can be modified using either the 
```plaintext
.output
```
 or 
```plaintext
.once
```
 commands. Pass in the desired output file location as a parameter. The 
```plaintext
.once
```
 command will only output the next set of results and then revert to standard out, but 
```plaintext
.output
```
 will redirect all subsequent output to that file location. Note that each result will overwrite the entire file at that destination. To revert back to standard output, enter 
```plaintext
.output
```
 with no file parameter.

In this example, the output format is changed to 
```plaintext
markdown
```
, the destination is identified as a Markdown file, and then DuckDB will write the output of the SQL statement to that file. Output is then reverted to standard output using 
```plaintext
.output
```
 with no parameter.

```
.mode markdown
.output my_results.md
SELECT 'taking flight' AS output_column;
.output
SELECT 'back to the terminal' AS displayed_column;
```

The file 
```plaintext
my_results.md
```
 will then contain:

```
| output_column |
|---------------|
| taking flight |
```

The terminal will then display:

```
|   displayed_column   |
|----------------------|
| back to the terminal |
```

A common output format is CSV, or comma separated values. DuckDB supports [SQL syntax to export data as CSV or Parquet](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/sql/statements/copy.html#copy-to), but the CLI-specific commands may be used to write a CSV instead if desired.

```
.mode csv
.once my_output_file.csv
SELECT 1 AS col_1, 2 AS col_2
UNION ALL
SELECT 10 AS col1, 20 AS col_2;
```

The file 
```plaintext
my_output_file.csv
```
 will then contain:

```csv
col_1,col_2
1,2
10,20
```

By passing special options (flags) to the 
```plaintext
.once
```
 command, query results can also be sent to a temporary file and automatically opened in the user's default program. Use either the 
```plaintext
-e
```
 flag for a text file (opened in the default text editor), or the 
```plaintext
-x
```
 flag for a CSV file (opened in the default spreadsheet editor). This is useful for more detailed inspection of query results, especially if there is a relatively large result set. The 
```plaintext
.excel
```
 command is equivalent to 
```plaintext
.once -x
```
.

```
.once -e
SELECT 'quack' AS hello;
```

The results then open in the default text file editor of the system, for example:

![Image 5: cli_docs_output_to_text_editor](http://duckdb.org/images/cli_docs_output_to_text_editor.jpg)

> Tip macOS users can copy the results to their clipboards using [```plaintext pbcopy ```](https://ss64.com/mac/pbcopy.html) by using 
> ```plaintext
> .once
> ```
>  to output to 
> ```plaintext
> pbcopy
> ```
>  via a pipe: 
> ```plaintext
> .once |pbcopy
> ```
> 
> 
> Combining this with the 
> ```plaintext
> .headers off
> ```
>  and 
> ```plaintext
> .mode lines
> ```
>  options can be particularly effective.

[Querying the Database Schema](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#querying-the-database-schema)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

All DuckDB clients support [querying the database schema with SQL](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/sql/meta/information_schema.html), but the CLI has additional [dot commands](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html) that can make it easier to understand the contents of a database. The 
```plaintext
.tables
```
 command will return a list of tables in the database. It has an optional argument that will filter the results according to a [```plaintext LIKE ``` pattern](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/sql/functions/pattern_matching.html#like).

```
CREATE TABLE swimmers AS SELECT 'duck' AS animal;
CREATE TABLE fliers AS SELECT 'duck' AS animal;
CREATE TABLE walkers AS SELECT 'duck' AS animal;
.tables
```

```
fliers    swimmers  walkers
```

For example, to filter to only tables that contain an 
```plaintext
l
```
, use the 
```plaintext
LIKE
```
 pattern 
```plaintext
%l%
```
.

```
.tables %l%
```

```
fliers   walkers
```

The 
```plaintext
.schema
```
 command will show all of the SQL statements used to define the schema of the database.

```
.schema
```

```
CREATE TABLE fliers (animal VARCHAR);
CREATE TABLE swimmers (animal VARCHAR);
CREATE TABLE walkers (animal VARCHAR);
```

[Progress Bar](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#progress-bar)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The DuckDB CLI client's progress bar supports customization through components.

The 
```plaintext
.progress_bar
```
 command supports 
```plaintext
--add
```
 and 
```plaintext
--clear
```
 parameters for adding and removing components.

For details on specific usage, see the examples below.

### [Configuring the Progress Bar Display](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#configuring-the-progress-bar-display)

To check if the progress bar is enabled:

```
SELECT * FROM duckdb_settings() WHERE name = 'enable_progress_bar';
```

To check the current minimum amount of time (in milliseconds) a query needs to take before displaying a progress bar:

```
SELECT * FROM duckdb_settings() WHERE name = 'progress_bar_time';
```

To set the minimum amount of time that the progress bar displays to 100 milliseconds:

```
SET progress_bar_time = 100;
```

To set that progress bar component to a red text that displays the current time on the progress bar:

```
.progress_bar --add "{align:right}{min_size:20}{color:red}Time: {sql:select (current_time::varchar).split('.')[1]}{color:reset} "
```

![Image 6: DuckDB progress bar with current time stamp](http://duckdb.org/images/progress_bar/duckdb_progressbar_time.gif)

> ```plaintext
> .progress_bar --add
> ```
>  commands are additive, issuing multiple 
> ```plaintext
> --add
> ```
>  calls will stack additional components on the progress bar.

To set that progress bar component to a blue text that displays the file cache RAM usage on the progress bar:

```
.progress_bar --add "{align:right}{min_size:20}{color:blue}External Cache Usage: {sql:select format_bytes(memory_usage_bytes) from duckdb_memory() where tag='EXTERNAL_FILE_CACHE'}{color:reset};
```

![Image 7: DuckDB progress bar with cache usage](http://duckdb.org/images/progress_bar/duckdb_progressbar_cache_usage.gif)

To resets all existing progress bar components:

```
.progress_bar --clear
```

[Syntax Highlighters](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#syntax-highlighters)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The DuckDB CLI client has a syntax highlighter for the SQL queries and another for the duckbox-formatted result tables.

### [Configuring the Query Syntax Highlighter](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#configuring-the-query-syntax-highlighter)

By default the shell includes support for syntax highlighting. The CLI's syntax highlighter can be configured using the following commands.

To turn off the highlighter:

```
.highlight off
```

To turn on the highlighter:

```
.highlight on
```

To configure the color used to highlight constants:

```
.constant [red|green|yellow|blue|magenta|cyan|white|brightblack|brightred|brightgreen|brightyellow|brightblue|brightmagenta|brightcyan|brightwhite]
```

```
.constantcode terminal_code
```

For example:

```
.constantcode 033[31m
```

To configure the color used to highlight keywords:

```
.keyword [red|green|yellow|blue|magenta|cyan|white|brightblack|brightred|brightgreen|brightyellow|brightblue|brightmagenta|brightcyan|brightwhite]
```

```
.keywordcode terminal_code
```

For example:

```
.keywordcode 033[31m
```

### [Configuring the Result Syntax Highlighter](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#configuring-the-result-syntax-highlighter)

By default, the result highlighting makes a few small modifications:

*   Bold column names.
*   ```plaintext
NULL
```
 values are greyed out.
*   Layout elements are grayed out.

The highlighting of each of the components can be customized using the 
```plaintext
.highlight_colors
```
 command. For example:

```
.highlight_colors layout red
.highlight_colors column_type yellow
.highlight_colors column_name yellow bold_underline
.highlight_colors numeric_value cyan underline
.highlight_colors temporal_value red bold
.highlight_colors string_value green bold
.highlight_colors footer gray
```

The result highlighting can be disabled using 
```plaintext
.highlight_results off
```
.

[Shorthands](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#shorthands)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

DuckDB's CLI allows using shorthands for dot commands. Once a sequence of characters can unambiguously completed to a dot command or an argument, the CLI (silently) autocompletes them. For example:

```
.mo ma
```

Is equivalent to:

```
.mode markdown
```

> Tip Avoid using shorthands in SQL scripts to improve readability and ensure that the scripts and futureproof.

[Importing Data from CSV](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#importing-data-from-csv)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

> Deprecated This feature is only included for compatibility reasons and may be removed in the future. Use the [```plaintext read_csv ``` function or the ```plaintext COPY ``` statement](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/data/csv/overview.html) to load CSV files.

DuckDB supports [SQL syntax to directly query or import CSV files](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/data/csv/overview.html), but the CLI-specific commands may be used to import a CSV instead if desired. The 
```plaintext
.import
```
 command takes two arguments and also supports several options. The first argument is the path to the CSV file, and the second is the name of the DuckDB table to create. Since DuckDB requires stricter typing than SQLite (upon which the DuckDB CLI is based), the destination table must be created before using the 
```plaintext
.import
```
 command. To automatically detect the schema and create a table from a CSV, see the [```plaintext read_csv ``` examples in the import docs](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/data/csv/overview.html).

In this example, a CSV file is generated by changing to CSV mode and setting an output file location:

```
.mode csv
.output import_example.csv
SELECT 1 AS col_1, 2 AS col_2 UNION ALL SELECT 10 AS col1, 20 AS col_2;
```

Now that the CSV has been written, a table can be created with the desired schema and the CSV can be imported. The output is reset to the terminal to avoid continuing to edit the output file specified above. The 
```plaintext
--skip N
```
 option is used to ignore the first row of data since it is a header row and the table has already been created with the correct column names.

```
.mode csv
.output
CREATE TABLE test_table (col_1 INTEGER, col_2 INTEGER);
.import import_example.csv test_table --skip 1
```

Note that the 
```plaintext
.import
```
 command utilizes the current 
```plaintext
.mode
```
 and 
```plaintext
.separator
```
 settings when identifying the structure of the data to import. The 
```plaintext
--csv
```
 option can be used to override that behavior.

```
.import import_example.csv test_table --skip 1 --csv
```

Documentation/Client APIs/CLI

Editing

> The linenoise-based CLI editor is currently only available for macOS and Linux.

DuckDB's CLI uses a line-editing library based on [linenoise](https://github.com/antirez/linenoise), which has shortcuts that are based on [Emacs mode of readline](https://readline.kablamo.org/emacs.html). Below is a list of available commands.

[Moving](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/editing.html#moving)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------

| Key | Action |
| --- | --- |
| ```plaintext Left ``` | Move back a character |
| ```plaintext Right ``` | Move forward a character |
| ```plaintext Up ``` | Move up a line. When on the first line, move to previous history entry |
| ```plaintext Down ``` | Move down a line. When on last line, move to next history entry |
| ```plaintext Home ``` | Move to beginning of buffer |
| ```plaintext End ``` | Move to end of buffer |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext Left ``` | Move back a word |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext Right ``` | Move forward a word |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext A ``` | Move to beginning of buffer |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext B ``` | Move back a character |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext E ``` | Move to end of buffer |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext F ``` | Move forward a character |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext Left ``` | Move back a word |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext Right ``` | Move forward a word |

[History](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/editing.html#history)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------

| Key | Action |
| --- | --- |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext P ``` | Move to previous history entry |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext N ``` | Move to next history entry |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext R ``` | Search the history |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext S ``` | Search the history |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext < ``` | Move to first history entry |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext > ``` | Move to last history entry |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext N ``` | Search the history |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext P ``` | Search the history |

[Changing Text](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/editing.html#changing-text)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

| Key | Action |
| --- | --- |
| ```plaintext Backspace ``` | Delete previous character |
| ```plaintext Delete ``` | Delete next character |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext D ``` | Delete next character. When buffer is empty, end editing |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext H ``` | Delete previous character |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext K ``` | Delete everything after the cursor |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext T ``` | Swap current and next character |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext U ``` | Delete all text |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext W ``` | Delete previous word |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext C ``` | Convert next word to titlecase |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext D ``` | Delete next word |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext L ``` | Convert next word to lowercase |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext R ``` | Delete all text |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext T ``` | Swap current and next word |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext U ``` | Convert next word to uppercase |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext Backspace ``` | Delete previous word |
| ```plaintext Alt ``` + ```plaintext \ ``` | Delete spaces around cursor |

[Completing](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/editing.html#completing)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

| Key | Action |
| --- | --- |
| ```plaintext Tab ``` | Autocomplete. When autocompleting, cycle to next entry |
| ```plaintext Shift ``` + ```plaintext Tab ``` | When autocompleting, cycle to previous entry |
| ```plaintext Esc ``` + ```plaintext Esc ``` | When autocompleting, revert autocompletion |

[Miscellaneous](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/editing.html#miscellaneous)
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

| Key | Action |
| --- | --- |
| ```plaintext Enter ``` | Execute query. If query is not complete, insert a newline at the end of the buffer |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext J ``` | Execute query. If query is not complete, insert a newline at the end of the buffer |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext C ``` | Cancel editing of current query |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext G ``` | Cancel editing of current query |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext L ``` | Clear screen |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext O ``` | Cancel editing of current query |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext X ``` | Insert a newline after the cursor |
| ```plaintext Ctrl ``` + ```plaintext Z ``` | Suspend CLI and return to shell, use ```plaintext fg ``` to re-open |

[External Editor Mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/editing.html#external-editor-mode)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Use 
```plaintext
.edit
```
 or 
```plaintext
\e
```
 to open a query in an external text editor.

*   When entered alone, it opens the previous command for editing.
*   When used inside a multi-line command, it opens the current command in the editor.

The editor is taken from the first set environment variable among 
```plaintext
DUCKDB_EDITOR
```
, 
```plaintext
EDITOR
```
 or 
```plaintext
VISUAL
```
 (in that order). If none are set, 
```plaintext
vi
```
 is used.

> This feature is only available in the linenoise-based CLI editor, which is currently supported on macOS and Linux.

[Using Read-Line](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/editing.html#using-read-line)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you prefer, you can use [```plaintext rlwrap ```](https://github.com/hanslub42/rlwrap) to use read-line directly with the shell. Then, use 
```plaintext
Shift
```
+
```plaintext
Enter
```
 to insert a newline and 
```plaintext
Enter
```
 to execute the query:

```
rlwrap --substitute-prompt="D " duckdb -batch
```

Known Issues

[Incorrect Memory Values on Old Linux Distributions and WSL 2](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/known_issues.html#incorrect-memory-values-on-old-linux-distributions-and-wsl-2)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

On Windows Subsystem for Linux 2 (WSL2), when querying the 
```plaintext
max_memory
```
 or 
```plaintext
memory_limit
```
 from the 
```plaintext
duckdb_settings
```
, the values may be inaccurate on certain Ubuntu versions (e.g., 20.04 and 24.04). The issue also occurs on older distributions such as Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8 (RHEL 8):

Example:

```
FROM duckdb_settings() WHERE name LIKE '%mem%';
```

The output contains values larger than 1000 PiB:

```
┌──────────────┬────────────┬─────────────────────────────────────────────┬────────────┬─────────┐
│     name     │   value    │                 description                 │ input_type │  scope  │
│   varchar    │  varchar   │                   varchar                   │  varchar   │ varchar │
├──────────────┼────────────┼─────────────────────────────────────────────┼────────────┼─────────┤
│ max_memory   │ 1638.3 PiB │ The maximum memory of the system (e.g. 1GB) │ VARCHAR    │ GLOBAL  │
│ memory_limit │ 1638.3 PiB │ The maximum memory of the system (e.g. 1GB) │ VARCHAR    │ GLOBAL  │
└──────────────┴────────────┴─────────────────────────────────────────────┴────────────┴─────────┘
```

Documentation/Client APIs/CLI

Output Formats

The 
```plaintext
.mode
```
[dot command](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html) may be used to change the appearance of the tables returned in the terminal output. In addition to customizing the appearance, these modes have additional benefits. This can be useful for presenting DuckDB output elsewhere by redirecting the terminal [output to a file](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/dot_commands.html#output-writing-results-to-a-file). Using the 
```plaintext
insert
```
 mode will build a series of SQL statements that can be used to insert the data at a later point. The 
```plaintext
markdown
```
 mode is particularly useful for building documentation and the 
```plaintext
latex
```
 mode is useful for writing academic papers.

[List of Output Formats](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html#list-of-output-formats)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

| Mode | Description |
| --- | --- |
| ```plaintext ascii ``` | Columns/rows delimited by 0x1F and 0x1E |
| ```plaintext box ``` | Tables using unicode box-drawing characters |
| ```plaintext csv ``` | Comma-separated values |
| ```plaintext column ``` | Output in columns (See ```plaintext .width ``` ) |
| ```plaintext duckbox ``` | Tables with extensive features (default) |
| ```plaintext html ``` | HTML ```plaintext <table> ``` code |
| ```sql insert TABLE ``` | SQL insert statements for ```sql TABLE ``` |
| ```plaintext json ``` | Results in a JSON array |
| ```plaintext jsonlines ``` | Results in a NDJSON |
| ```plaintext latex ``` | LaTeX tabular environment code |
| ```plaintext line ``` | One value per line |
| ```plaintext list ``` | Values delimited by ```plaintext | ``` |
| ```plaintext markdown ``` | Markdown table format |
| ```plaintext quote ``` | Escape answers as for SQL |
| ```plaintext table ``` | ASCII-art table |
| ```plaintext tabs ``` | Tab-separated values |
| ```plaintext tcl ``` | TCL list elements |
| ```plaintext trash ``` | No output |

[Changing the Output Format](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html#changing-the-output-format)
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Use the vanilla 
```plaintext
.mode
```
 dot command to query the appearance currently in use.

```
.mode
```

```
current output mode: duckbox
```

Use the 
```plaintext
.mode
```
 dot command with an argument to set the output format.

```
.mode markdown
SELECT 'quacking intensifies' AS incoming_ducks;
```

```
|    incoming_ducks    |
|----------------------|
| quacking intensifies |
```

The output appearance can also be adjusted with the 
```plaintext
.separator
```
 command. If using an export mode that relies on a separator (
```plaintext
csv
```
 or 
```plaintext
tabs
```
 for example), the separator will be reset when the mode is changed. For example, 
```plaintext
.mode csv
```
 will set the separator to a comma (
```plaintext
,
```
). Using 
```plaintext
.separator "|"
```
 will then convert the output to be pipe-separated.

```
.mode csv
SELECT 1 AS col_1, 2 AS col_2
UNION ALL
SELECT 10 AS col1, 20 AS col_2;
```

```csv
col_1,col_2
1,2
10,20
```

```
.separator "|"
SELECT 1 AS col_1, 2 AS col_2
UNION ALL
SELECT 10 AS col1, 20 AS col_2;
```

```csv
col_1|col_2
1|2
10|20
```

[```plaintext duckbox ``` Mode](http://duckdb.org/docs/stable/clients/cli/output_formats.html#duckbox-mode)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By default, DuckDB renders query results in 
```plaintext
duckbox
```
 mode, which is a feature-rich ASCII-art style output format.

The duckbox mode supports the 
```plaintext
large_number_rendering
```
 option, which allows human-readable rendering of large numbers. It has three levels:

*   ```plaintext
off
```
 – All numbers are printed using regular formatting.
*   ```plaintext
footer
```
 (default) – Large numbers are augmented with the human-readable format. Only applies to single-row results.
*   ```plaintext
all
```
 - All large numbers are replaced with the human-readable format.

See the following examples:

```
.large_number_rendering off
SELECT pi() * 1_000_000_000 AS x;
```

```
┌───────────────────┐
│         x         │
│      double       │
├───────────────────┤
│ 3141592653.589793 │
└───────────────────┘
```

```
.large_number_rendering footer
SELECT pi() * 1_000_000_000 AS x;
```

```
┌───────────────────┐
│         x         │
│      double       │
├───────────────────┤
│ 3141592653.589793 │
│  (3.14 billion)   │
└───────────────────┘
```

```
.large_number_rendering all
SELECT pi() * 1_000_000_000 AS x;
```

```
┌──────────────┐
│      x       │
│    double    │
├──────────────┤
│ 3.14 billion │
└──────────────┘
```
